Thursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITIEE 11539 Thursday, 27 November 1997 1997 Second Reading Debate resumed from 26 November, on motion by Ms Worth: That the bill be now read a second time. Ms WORTH (Adelaide-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services) (10.02 a.m.},-in reply-I would like to briefly sum up the debate yesterday which followed the second reading speech on the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Amendment Bill. There were contributions from colleagues in the opposition and the government, and I would like to place on the record my gratitude to my colleagues for ensuring that this bill went through as smoothly as it did. The bill ensures that some small changes will take place-principally, that the roles of the now full-time chair and full-time CEO will change to those of part-time chair and full-time CEO. This really shows the understanding of the government-and the opposition as well, for that matter-of the extraordinary amount of important work being done at ANZFA. Reforms such as the food hygiene review, the review of food regulation, the review of food standards and the national uniform food legislation are all important matters going on there currently, and it will be a particularly busy year next year. I would like to acknowledge my colleague the member for Bendigo, Mr Reid. He mentioned that he had launched national food safety awareness week in his electorate. I encourage all my colleagues to promote such community events whenever they have the opportunity-as I had in Sydney and also in Adelaide-to promote community awareness of just how simply things can be done to promote people's health. Again, I acknowledge my own gratitude and that of the government to those members who contributed to this debate. I am pleased to have had their support. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. in detail. The question now is that this bill be reported to the House without amendment. Question resolved in the affirmative. CORPORA TIONS LAW AMENDMENT (ASX) BILL 1997 Second Reading Consideration resumed from 19 November. a.m.)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time.

title: Representatives Main Commitiee

speaker: Mr Miles (Braddon
theText: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister) (10.0411540 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 27 November 19-7 More than a third of Australian adults-some 4.7 million people-now have investments in the share market. Efficient capital markets are central to the government's objective of achieving higher economic growth and facilitating private sector investment, employment generation and wealth creation. Economic growth depends on the investment of the sayings of Australians in productive and innovative ways. Efficient, well supervised securities markets are a vital component of our capital markets and are one of the most important vehicles for economic growth. They provide investment opportunities, enable companies to raise capital, act as an efficient price discovery mechanism, and help to channel resources and savings to their most productive uses. Strategies to promote the standing of our securities markets must be adopted in order to achieve the government's foremost objectives of promoting growth, attracting investment to Australia and creating employment. . . The Australian Stock Exchange, the ASX, as Australia's leading securities market, plays a central role in the efficient operation of the Australian economy. It provides a marketplace for the trading of the securities of Australia's leading companies. In reflecting the collective information and judgment of investors, the exchange channels investors' capital into its most productive uses. By bringing together parties wishing to buy and sell securities, the exchange facilitates price discovery and reduces transaction costs and settlement risks. The savings of millions of Australians are invested directly or indirectly through the exchange. The privatisation of one-third of Telstra, together with the recent demutualisations of National Mutual Holdings and Colonial Ltd, will add to the overall market capitalisation of the exchange. In addition, the ASX, in its capacity as a market regulator, is the front line regulator of the day-to-day operations of the market. The ASX is, therefore, an important national asset and a cornerstone of our capital markets. The ASX is currently organised and governed in a manner that is traditional for stock exchanges. It is a 'cooperative' or mutual. Since their origins in coffee shop meetings of stockbrokers in London and Amsterdam four centuries ago, most stock exchanges around the world have come to be structured as mutual organisations of stockbrokers. The exchange is owned and controlled by its members and run on behalf of its members under its own constitution and operating rules. Its members are the brokers who use the exchange to deal in the securities of businesses and governments. They are either corporations or firms that are licensed stockbroking organisations, or individuals who are senior employees .or directors of stockbroking organisations. Only recently has the continuing appropriateness of this structure been challenged. Substantial changes to. the commercial and international environments in which stock exchanges operate have obliged exchanges to radically rethink their corporate governance structures. In 1993, the Stockholm Stock Exchange chose to become a limited liability company whose shares are freely traded. Recently, other European exchanges have altered their governance structures in one form or another. Stock exchanges operate in a dynamic, competitive and rapidly changing environment that is far removed from the circumstances of yesterday. The world financial system has witnessed dramatic changes and exponential growth over recent decades. New technologies have allowed an increasing range of financial services to be supplied across international borders. Recent events in the world's stock markets highlight the increasing international interdependence of those markets. Thursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 11541 Exchanges must continually appraise and, if necessary, adapt their governance structures to meet new demands and competitive pressures. The ASX initiated a review of its governance structure in 1995. That review concluded that the ASX should demutualise and go one step further than any other stock exchange by listing on its own market and having its shares quoted. In October 1996, after considering a business case prepared for them, members of the ASX voted to 'demutualise' the exchange-that is, to convert the exchange from a company limited by guarantee to a company limited by shares. That company would ,be owned and controlled by its shareholders and conducted as a conventional business for the purpose of yielding a return to its owners. The ASX is, essentially, a private body. It is not funded by government in the role that it carries out. The government accepts that the internal governance of the exchange is, in the first instance, a matter for the exchange and its owners. The government has agreed in this bill to facilitate the conversion of the exchange to a public company. However, the proposal does raise an important issue for government-namely, how is it to ensure that the public interest in the proper running of the exchange is protected following the proposed changes to the ASX's governance arrangements? The ASX undertakes three roles within the securities industry. It is a market regulator, a selfregulatory organisation or SRO; a commercial entity conducting a public securities market as a business; and a trade association seeking to protect and promote the interests of its members. The regulatory responsibilities of the ASX The ASX's listing rules perform an important role in the regulation of listed companies. In making and administering these rules, the ASX occupies a formal, statutorily recognised position in the system of co-regulation of companies and securities with the Australian Securities Commission, the ASC. Important services provided by the ASX include the maintenance of market integrity, fair trading systems, guarantees of trade completion, clearing, settlement and transfer systems and information about stock that is traded. The maintenance of market integrity encompasses a number of important facets, including ensuring investors are properly and fully informed about matters affecting listed companies so that their shares can be fairly priced, having trading and settlement systems that are fair and efficient, ensuring that stockbrokers deal fairly and honestly with their clients, and detecting any attempt to mislead the market. Markets characterised by the presence of these elements attract broad investor participation. It is essential that the Australian Stock Exchange continues to ensure the honesty and integrity of .the securities market for which it is responsible. The conversion of the exchange to a company limited by shares represents a significant change to the way in which stock exchanges have traditionally been conducted. The issue, from a policy perspective, is whether the commercial pressures of a 'for profit' entity will undermine the commitment of resources and capabilities of the exchange to effectively fulfil its regulatory and public interest responsibilities to an appropriate standard. To ensure appropriate levels of investor protection, the Corporations Law will be amended to clarify the responsibilities of the Australian Stock Exchange as an SRO, and ensure there is appropriate accountability of the Australian Stock Exchange to the ASC and the government in carrying out its SRO responsibilities. 11542 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 27 November 1997 The law will impose obligations on the exchange to do everything necessary to ensure that the market it conducts is an orderly and fair market, and self-regulatory functions are carried out on an ongoing basis. It will, in particular, require the exchange to have adequate arrangements for overseeing stockbrokers, for the settlement of transactions and for investigating complaints by investors about business transacted on the market. To ensure appropriate compliance with these obligations, the bill will empower the minister to direct the exchange to attend to certain matters that the minister believes will promote compliance with the ongoing obligations. In addition, the bill will provide for an annual report by the exchange of its performance of its SRO responsibilities. Supervision of a listed Australian Stock Exchange The Australian Stock Exchange proposes that its shares be listed on its own exchange. As the Australian Stock Exchange is responsible for the administration and enforcement of the listing rules against all listed companies, there would be a conflict of interest in the Australian Stock Exchange monitoring its compliance with, and enforcing, its listing rules against itself. To remove the potential for any conflict of interest, the bill provides for the ASC to undertake the supervision of the Australian Stock Exchange's compliance with the listing rules. The Australian Stock Exchange will meet these supervisory costs. Restrictions on the ownership of shares in the Australian Stock Exchange Given the critical role it plays in the national economy, it would not be in the public interest for anyone party to gain control of the Australian Stock Exchange. The bill thus imposes a statutory limitation of five per cent on individual shareholdings in the Australian Stock Exchange. A limitation of this order will encourage diverse ownership of the Australian Stock Exchange. The five per cent limitation will apply to both Australians and foreigners. The regulation of stockbrokers Under the current law, stockbrokers must be members of stock exchanges, and stock exchanges must ensure that their members are of good character and conduct themselves accordingly when trading on an exchange. Following demutualisation, the right to trade on the Australian Stock Exchange will be available to appropriately qualified and financially sound organisations, whether or not they are members of the Australian Stock Exchange. Access to the market will be based on a contract between the Australian Stock Exchange and brokers. Those contractual arrangements will not require any ownership interest in the Australian Stock Exchange, as at present. While the bill recognises the Australian Stock Exchange's altered relationship with brokers, at the same time it ensures that the Australian Stock Exchange continues to be responsible for the conduct and integrity of market participants trading on the Australian Stock Exchange and in related activities. Access to the National Guarantee Fund On its conversion to a public company, further approvals of payments from the National Guarantee Fund, the NGF, for the Australian Stock Exchange's own development would not be available. Such approvals, in circumstances where the benefits of the capital investments funded by those moneys would inappropriately accrue to shareholders of the Australian Stock Exchange, will no longer be appropriate. There is no need to make specific provision for these changed circumstances in this bill. The Corporations Law presently confers a broad discretion on the minister in approving payments out of the National Guarantee Fund for the development of the securities industry. Thursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 11543 Within the scope of this discretion, the government proposes that guidelines be developed detailing the circumstances in which payments from the fund may be approved in light of the ASX's changed circumstances. It is anticipated that payments will continue to be approved for such purposes as investor education and campaign or research projects that will enhance the development of Australia's securities markets, but not for capital development of the exchange. Conclusion In summary, the bill provides a mechanism for the conversion of the exchange to a public company. In so doing it gives effect to the decision of members as to the governance arrangements they consider appropriate for the ASX into the next century. Legislation is necessary to effect this change as the Corporations Law does not presently permit a company limited by guarantee to change its status to that of a company limited by shares through administrative procedures, nor facilitate the breaking of the nexus between ownership of a stock exchange and access to the market .operated by that exchange. More importantly, however, legislation is necessary to clarify the responsibilities of a demutualised ASX as a self-regulatory organisation, or SRO, and ensure appropriate accountability of the ASX to the ASC and the government in meeting those responsibilities. Where appropriate, the clarification of these responsibilities will have application to securities exchanges generally, and not solely to the ASX. The measures proposed by this bill will assist the ASX to compete with regional exchanges and enhance the international competitiveness of Australia's financial sector in the Asia-Pacific region. They will help to deliver significant new employment, income and wealth to the Australian community. The bill is not expected to have any significant financial impact on government. While additional costs will be incurred by the ASC in supervising the listing of the ASX, the ASX has agreed to reimburse the ASC for these costs. In accordance with the corporations agreement between the Commonwealth, the states and the Northern Territory on corporate regulation, the Ministerial Council for Corporations has been consulted and has approved the introduction of the bill into parliament. I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill and I commend the bill to the House. Bill 1997 proposes to facilitate the decision by the Australian Stock Exchange to demutualise-that is, to change from a company limited by guarantee to a public company limited by shares-and to list on its own market. The evolution of this bill goes back to a review in 1995 that the ASX initiated of its own structure. That review concluded that the ASX should demutualise, something which had been done by a number of exchanges internationally, and, in addition, that it should do what no other exchange had done: list its own stock. Iri October last year, the ASX members-the stockbrokers-voted to demutualise. Exchanges in other countries, such as Sweden, have demutualised but none have, apparently, been listed before. So this does represent a groundbreaking decision by the ASX. The ASX presently is a private cooperative or mutual company which performs a number of multiple roles simultaneously. First, it operates a securities market as a business; second, it acts as regulator for listed companies; and, third, it operates as a trade association for its member stockbrokers. The key issue arising from this legislation is: are these roles compromised by the new, demutualised structure?
title: Representatives Main Commitiee

speaker: Mr Kelvin Thomson (Wills) (10.17 A.m.}
theText: The Corporations Law Amendment (AS X)11544 MAIN COMMITIEE Thursday, 27 November 1997 The advice that we have received from the government, from the ASX and from the industry is that the answer to that question is no, the change of structure ought to provide an opportunity to clarify and improve existing arrangements; it should not involve any imprudent risks. Accordingly, the opposition supports this legislation. To ensure adequate levels of investor protection, the Corporations Law is to be amended to ensure that the ASX, and other exchanges, are accountable to the general company regulator, the Australian Securities Commission. Specifically, obligations will be imposed on the ASX, and exchanges generally, to do everything necessary to ensure that the market it conducts is an orderly and fair one, and that self-regulatory functions are carried out on an ongoing basis. This should ensure the continued proper operation of the market. Indeed, there is no doubt that it is in the commercial interests of the ASX to run an orderly, efficient market. Having a specific profit motive should assist in that motivation to continue to run the market properly. Clearly, as the ASX will be listing on its own exchange, there will be a conflict of interest in overseeing itself. Therefore, the ASC will supervise the ASX's compliance with the listing rules. This provision has the agreement of the ASX and is a necessary alteration to accommodate the demutualisation. In addition, the bill will also free up the regulation of stockbrokers. Currently, stockbrokers must be members of stock exchanges and stock exchanges must ensure the good character and conduct of their members. Following demutualisation, the right to trade will be available to all appropriately qualified and financially sound organisations, whether or not they are members of the ASX. However, the ASX will continue to be responsible for the condur! and integrity of market participants trading on the ASX and in related activities. This is J. worthwhile reform freeing up access to the ASX which has the support of the opposition. The other major decision in the bill is the limitation of individual holdings to five per cent of the issued capital. This limitation applies to both resident and non-resident shareholders. This is a necessary public interest regulation which will ensure that, although the ASX will be fully commercialised, the national interest lies in preventing a takeover of a cornerstone of Australia's capital markets. The opposition is supportive of the legislation. We wish the ASX success in its new structure. We are indebted to ASX representatives for their assistance in explaining some of the relevant issues to us. There are a number of issues concerning market regulation and confidence which ought to be raised in a debate of this kind. I and other members of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities raised with the Australian Securities Commission aspects of their role in overseeing the ASX and sought their assurance that the changes which were going to occur would not compromise the integrity of the ASX. The committee received the following advice from the head of the ASC, Mr Cameron: We will assume directly only a small additional rolethe role that I referred to earlierand that is to supervise their own listing when that occurs, because they cannot be seen to be the body that gives themselves exemptions from their listing rules and monitors their compliance with the listing rules and so on. So we will do that. Thursday; 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 11545 Mr Cameron went on to express the personal view: ... when the stock exchange becomes a publicly quoted corporation and is no longer directly controlled by 'the' braking industry as such, when it is controlled by investors seeking to make a profit out of the trading on the exchange, then the assumptions that you would otherwise have made about the enforcement of professional standards, the role that the stock exchange ought to perform at the moment and does perform at the moment and will continue to perform, the judgments they make in that will be more difficult. They will have a greater tension between their role of immediately trying to make a profit for their invest()rs, for their owners, and the other role of maintaining the credibility of the market. He goes on to say-and I think this is right: In the long term they are not in conflict because long term the credibility of the market is crucial to its long-term profitability. But there is a short-term tension at least between those objectives. I think that will mean that a new regulatory paradigm has to emerge when the exchange is privately owned. That will be a process of time. That was the sort of response that we in the committee received from the ASC to questions about the issues involved in this bill. I further make the point that the ASX has noted its in its annual report that funding for the Australian Securities Commission will fall from $104 million in 1996 to $74 million in 1997. Given the importance of the ASC in maintaining that most critical asset of market integrity, it is a matter of some concern to us that the ASC budget has been reduced in this way. In addition, if we are going to talk about the issue of public confidence in the ASX, there is no doubt that it is essential that the public believe that all investors and all those who deal in shares are treated on an equal basis. That is why it was a matter of great public concern that we saw revelations earlier this year on the Four Comers program concerning the activities of the Victorian Premier Kennett in apparently telephoning the former chairman of the Australian Stock Exchange, Laurie Cox, to secure shares in the Arthur Yates float. That was a hot float, and members might recall that Stephen Mayne reported on the Four Comers program that he had made inquiries on behalf of Premier Kennett as to whether shares in Arthur Yates could be obtained. He reported back that he had made inquiries and had established from the brokers that all the shares were allocated. But, according to Stephen Mayne, Premier Kennett contacted the chairman of the Stock Exchange, Laurie Cox, and emerged with 20,000 Yates shares for his wife Felicity. It is a matter of considerable public concern if there is the impression that some shareholders, or prospective share owners, are treated differently from others and that brokers apply different rules between clients. member. Interestingly, Premier Kennett has said that he could not remember whether he telephoned Laurie Cox concerning this matter. Mr Cox has refused to be interviewed about the matter and has refused to deny that he received a call from Mr Kennett, who was seeking shares in Yates. which managed that float back in 1993. That is correct. But if you were an ordinary member of the public you could not get shares concerning that float.

theText: The head of the ASC said that:11548 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 27 November 1997 He went on to say that the ASC works closely with the ASX in these matters. In the circumstances, these are matters which the ASC and the ASX need to investigate to make sure that behaviour by brokers which damages the reputation of the Stock Exchange is not tolerated. Those points having been made-and they are important points of public interest which need to be made so that public confidence in the ASX does not suffer as a result of the kinds of revelations made by Stephen Mayne and others-there needs to be a proper investigation of those matters. speaker: Mrs Johnston (Canning) (10.37 A.m.)
theText: I will restrict my comments this morning moreThursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 11549 previous government, which had 13 years to do something about this bill and about other areas and which did not consider it necessary to do anything which would enable the business community to respond in a much better way. This is what the coalition understands, and again I stress that those on the opposite side failed to adequately grasp that a fundamental key to achieving greater economic growth is to give priority to business. I should hope, even though it has not happened in the past, that in the future all members in this place recognise this, because it is only by helping business to operate more efficiently that wealth can and will be created and that employment is generated. I am also a member of the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities, and I particularly welcome the changes that this bill will bring about. The Australian Stock Exchange, Australia's leading securities market, acts as the hub of the securities trading in the Australian economy. The ASX mission statement, on page 2 of the 1996 ASX annual report, has been defined as follows: To provide for the benefit of all participants, the most internationally competitive and fair market for financial securities and derivatives so as to enhance Australia's position as a regional financial centre. The Australian Stock Exchange is the 10th largest national equities market in the world and the largest in the Southern Hemisphere. It is one of the most technologically sophisticated equities markets in the world. Indeed, the ASX is a credit to our nation-and it is a shame that some people seem to want to use it as a tool to put their scurrilous allegations around. The frantic buying and selling atmosphere of the ASX reflects the hectic activity of the industry and the speed at which money changes hands in the new world economy. Because of the fast paced exchanges of information and capital in the 1990s, Australians cannot just look to the past and commend themselves on their successful efforts thus far, but rather we need to look forward and prepare for the next millennium. If we fail to meet the challenges presented to us we will be left behind-there is no doubt about that. Not only will we be isolated geographically but we will be isolated technologically as well. The decision to convert to a public company was not taken lightly. In deliberating over the option to demutualise, the board of the ASX considered the advice of external consultants who responded in the following way. They said: A mutual structure inhibited the flexibility and speed of decision-making that was necessary to meet growing competition ... This is from page 6 of the same ASX annual report that I referred to earlier. The members of the ASX in October 1996 voted overwhelmingly to demutualise the exchange, that is, to convert the ASX from a company limited by guarantee to a company limited by shares. The Howard government, in giving speedy passage to this bill, ensures that Australia will not be left behind in providing an efficient marketplace for the trading of securities by Australia's leading companies. The overwhelming success of the recent Telstra float demonstrates that millions of Australians, from all walks of life, are positively embracing the share market as a real investment option for their hard-earned dollars. Indeed, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator Ian Campbell) alluded to in his second reading speech, more than 4.7 million Australians have investments in the share market. Proceeds of some $14 billion are expected from the sale of one-third of Telstra-I am not quite sure what we have actually got by now-and 81 per cent of this has been secured into Australian hands. That is good news for Australian families as well as for Australian businesses. 11550 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 27 November 1997 The rollover of private savings into business investment, which facilitates economic growth, requires the implementation of innovative and productive approaches to corporate governance structures. As shown by the demutilalisation of the Stockholm exchange in 1993, the conversion of the ASX into a public company will provide the mechanism for enhanced competitiveness of Australian capital markets, both internationally and domestically. The role of the ASX within the securities industry is threefold. Firstly, it acts as a market regulator. Secondly, it acts as a commercial entity conducting a public securities market as a business. Thirdly, it acts as a trade association protecting and promoting its members' interests. Under current arrangements the ASX is, in essence, a private body. It is a body which is not funded by government. However, in saying that, this legislation is necessary due to the fact that the Corporations Law does not allow a body such as the ASX to change its status to a public company under current administrative procedures. Moreover, legislation is required to ensure that, although converted, the ASX remains subject to appropriate accountability procedures. To achieve this the government, as well as the Australian Securities Commission, will oversee that the ASX is meeting its responsibilities. The demutualisation of the ASX will not diminish its market integrity or fair trading systems. The potential for conflict of interest has been removed with supervision by the Australian Securities Commission. Moreover, given the pivotal role the ASX plays in the nation's economy, the public interest of all Australians has been protected by the five per cent limit on shares available to both domestic and foreign investors. The coalition government, in formulating this bill, consulted with the states and territories and they all agreed upon this legislation. There is no financial impact to this measure. It is not a cost cutting measure, and neither does it have any significant financial impact on government. The Corporations Law Amendment (ASX) Bill 1997 represents plain good business sense, and we on this side of the House all recognise that it is good business decisions that serve to increase the wealth generating capacity of companies and individuals who in tum provide employment opportunities for Australian people. Job creation is the outcome of that: an outcome that we on this side of the House are taking action to encourage. It is on this positive note that I commend the bill to the House. Corporations Law Amendment (AS X) Bill 1997. In a nutshell, the bill will facilitate the demutualisation of the Australian Stock Exchange as the ASX changes its status from a mutual company to a publicly listed company limited by shares, with external ownership and operated for profit. The giant leap of faith by members of the ASX to demutualise occurred at a vote of its members in October of last year. That decision was based on business principles. This bill attempts to facilitate the proposed changes to the Australian Stock Exchange governance arrangements whilst at the same time ensuring that the role of the Australian Stock Exchange in the regulatory framework is not diminished or impaired at the risk of shareholders, companies and our nation's growing reputation as the key financial player in the South-East Asian basin. This will be achieved, principally, in four significant ways. Firstly, it will clarify the responsibilities of the Australian Stock Exchange, as a self-regulatory organisation, to ensure appropriate accountability of it to the Australian Securities Commission and the government.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Bob Baldwin (Paterson) (10.45 A.m.)
theText: It gives me great pleasure to speak on theThursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITfEE 11551 Secondly, it will continue the role of the Australian Securities Commission to supervise Australian Stock Exchange compliance with the listing rules in respect of the ASX's own listing. The Australian Stock Exchange will be listing on a market in which it acts as a selfregulator and administrator, hence the arms-length provision legislated to ensure the ongoing integrity of the Australian Stock Exchange. Thirdly, the bill will recognise the Australian Stock Exchange's altered relationship with brokers, and clarifies that as a corporate entity it will continue to be responsible for the conduct and integrity of market participants in trading on the Stock Exchange and in other activities. Fourthly, it limits individual Australian investors and foreign investors to owning and controlling no more than five per cent of the shares in the Australian Stock Exchange. This five per cent limit, which stands in contrast to the current individual limit on bank ownership of 10 per cent, shows, if nothing else, to the man or woman in the. street the principled financial integrity of this bill. That five per cent limit ensures that no significant foreign investment player will obtain a controlling interest in the Australian Stock Exchange. The figure could, in the eyes of some, seem a little ironic-especially when the recent Wallis inquiry into the financial sector painted the genuine picture that banks should be allowed to raise their restricted individual ownership levels from 10 per cent to 15 per cent-but I think it is an important irony and I will quickly explain why. The Australian Stock Exchange is generally perceived to be philosophically opposed to companies having share ownership restrictions-if for nothing else but to avoid a restriction on the depth of an individual listed company's share register, levels of liquidity or, potentially, stifled share trading. Why the restriction? The decision to restrict is one instilled by the current government to ensure that financial integrity and confidence in dealing with the Australian capital markets are enshrined. The decision is also about delivering peace of mind to the small, but extremely important, mum and dad investors in large investment houses and corporate share traders. The Australian financial market-for all its integrity, for all its hordes of commentators, brokers, market analysts, and for all the attention it receives-is, of course, a minor player in the global marketplace. Yes, we stand on our own two feet as the ongoing repercussions in parts of the Asian financial sector day by day is proving. But we cannot be seen, in this time of volatile world financial markets in particular, to be providing foreign investment players or overseas corporates with even a sniff that Australia is prepared to put its own market self-regulator even remotely in the control of anyone, two or three individual corporate entities, be they foreign or local. The bill is also about maintaining our Al financial integrity within the Australian capital markets. It would be fair to say that a fifth key element of the bill, in light of the members of the Australian Stock Exchange who voted overwhelmingly to demutualise, is that it amends the Corporations Law to permit the Australian Stock Exchange to change from a company limited by guarantee to one limited by shares. As the market regulator and overriding key player in Australia's capital markets, the Australian Stock Exchange presently acts as the national exchange for the trading of shares, bonds, notes and debentures of over 1,200 Australian and overseas companies, other entities, government and corporate. In terms of market capitalisation, it ranks 11th in world standing. As of 31 December 1996, its domestic market capitalisation was a quite incredible $392.8 billion. Annual turnover for 11552 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 27 November 1997 the 1996 year was $185.8 billion, which was undertaken via 4.7 million separate transactions. These figures vindicate the record equities market activity which has occurred on the Australian Stock Exchange over the past year. They are the kinds of figures that would make somebody like Karl Marx tum over in his grave, along with those who have followed in modem history since that abhor the concept of capital markets. They are figures that show that a growing number of Australians are importantly investing in the Stock Exchange and are confident of putting part of their savings into equity investments. Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not need to remind you of the Telstra float and how successful that was, in particular for the mums and dads of Australia. These are the kinds of figures which have acted as the foundation rock for the recently successful part privatisation ofTelstra and its listing on the Australian Stock Exchange. Share investment has become a way of life in the 1990s and this bill is a way of ensuring that the integrity of the market and the integrity of the Australian Stock Exchange in general is kept. When I add that the Australian Stock Exchange, perhaps not as an entity but as the selfregulator of the Australian Stock Exchange per se, has achieved an important position in the general public's thinking and investment strategies, I wish to digress towards some wonderful developments occurring in relation to capital markets in the Hunter region. The Hunter, to a lot of people, would not be even considered as a potential new growth market for the financial sector. I urge the members of this House to think again. The Stock Exchange of Newcastle is presently in the midst of doing something very visionary for the Hunter and has set in train a new industry with immense employment opportunities for the 21st century. The exchange, which is now in its 60th year of existence, is in the process of completing a review and restructure of its operations to enable it to conduct a stock marketyes, an individual stock market in the Hunter-that specialises in the securities of small, medium and regional enterprises. In layman's terms, the exchange is attempting to reactivate the establishing of an electronic trading system within the Hunter to operate a fully-fledged alternative equity market. Its moves to do so were the result of the members of the exchange wanting to assist thousands of small to medium enterprises across Australia who are seeking additional equity capital of between $500,000 and $1 million and, of course, more. I might take the time to remind people that one of Australia's most successful companies, Brambles, had its beginnings by listing on the Newcastle Stock Exchange many years ago. The stock exchange's vision is being matched by the federal government's general approach to reform of fundraising for businesses, particularly for small to medium enterprises, under the corporate law economic reform program. Similarly, it is a forerunner to what could be expected should the government look favourably on the yet to be released Study of a growth equity market for Australia, which was prepared for the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism( Mr Moore) by the Catalyst Institute. The report will be the end result of an inquiry into the range of problems associated with small to medium enterprises obtaining effective access to effective equity finance. I very much envisage the Stock Exchange of Newcastle's proposal for a vibrant alternative equity market-upon its approval by the ASC, where, as I understand it, developments are progressing well-will vindicate the government's thinking that alternative equity markets have a place in Australia, not so much to compete with the Australian Stock Exchange as to carry Thursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 11553 the excess companies who do not perceive the value of being, or simply cannot be afford to be, on the main board. From day one, since my election to this House, I fervently backed the Stock Exchange of Newcastle's proposal-a proposal driven by the likes of John Tonkin, Chairman of the exchange, and directors Barry Rees and Stephen Pritchard. There is a reason I have stuck my neck out to do what it takes; to lobby the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator Ian Campbell, on the merits of this proposal, and to put John Moore continually in the picture. If the government is keen to facilitate the development of alternative equity markets, here is a perfect example of what can be achieved both in jobs and in facilitated new investment and immense opportunities linked to this project. That primary reason is jobs, and plenty of new jobs in an exciting new industry sector for the Hunter. County NatWest Securities, one of the leading financial houses, believes that 2,500 new long-term jobs and an upgrading of the skills base of employment across the Hunter are just two very realistic and possible outcomes if the proposed trading facilities of the Newcastle Stock Exchange get the necessary support of my government. That support, of course, comes in the form of the ASC which, under both the existing Corporations Law and the intentions behind the CLERP reforms, must for financial integrity ensure that the Newcastle Stock Exchange stacks up on paper. As the relevant i's are dotted and t's are crossed, I believe that will occur; and Senator Ian Campbell himself is quite excited about the merits of the exchange's ideas. It makes you wonder why neither the former Keating government nor Labor fellow Hunter parliamentarians showed little interest in exploring the depths that fostering alternative equity provisions for small to medium enterprises could achieve for regional economies, let alone for the greater Australian economic picture. In due course, along with my colleague, Hunter based Senator John Tierney, I will be pushing the case for the Stock Exchange of Newcastle to Ipeet the necessary regulatory hurdles to become a part of the government's new industry vision for this nation and for the Hunter. That push will also continue on a financial front, at the appropriate time. I have already had long discussions with the member for Ballarat( Mr Ronaldson), who is the government's key driver of the Commonwealth's $10 million commitment to the Hunter-as part of the joint state-BHP financial support package-about the immense merits of the stock exchange'S proposals and assistance in funding an electronic trading platform. Such a platform would cost anywhere between $500,000 and $700,000-which I think produces a very good return on investment for jobs, if we can help foster 2,500 created jobs out of the Newcastle Stock Exchange in the years ahead. My push to secure Commonwealth dollars through that avenue of funding will continue unabashed and unabated. Let us not forget the net loss from BHP at the end of 1999 in Newcastle is that same figure. Mr Deputy Speaker, if you question my excitable support for the proposal-which is anything but pie in the sky-the words of the Newcastle Stock Exchange Chairman, John Tonkin, in a recent press statement, will lay the significance of a proposal down on the table. He said: This is a very exciting initiative, with real upside potential for jobs and investment in the Hunter. Local Hunter Parliamentarian Bob Baldwin, who has been a powerful lobbyist and go-between to entice Commonwealth interest in the proposed creation of an operative alternative equity market within the Hunter from day one, along with Senator Tierney, have both overseen the preparation of the submission. 11554 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 27 November 1997 Both Parliamentarians to their credit, have given their support and real commitment to the project. The Hunter has many firms who would benefit greatly from an injection of capital. They are his words, not mine. Also, I bring to the House's attention a newspaper article of 20 November of this year, entitled 'Money on for bigger city stock exchange', a report by Scott Tucker. Rather than take up the time of this chamber, I seek leave to have that article incorporated in the Hansard. It has been agreed to by the opposition. you can only put figures in and not text. of jobs and public investment in established and emerging regional industries, if a proposal to the Australian Securities Commission and Federal Government gains support. The Stock Exchange of Newcastle Limited is awaiting feedback on its submission and hopes the Minister for Industry, Mr Moore, will provide federal funds, possibly through the Hunter Advantage Fund, to help establish local trading. It says the proposal, which followed the release of a report by County NatWest Securities Australia Limited into the commercial potential of small to medium businesses in the Hunter, would offer many financial and social benefits to the region. The Newcastle trading proposal has won support from a range of regional business leaders, including Australian Business Limited, Newcastle Regional Chamber of Commerce, Newcastle Law Society, the Australian Society of Practising Accountants and the Institute of Chartered Accountants. 'Some 2500 long-term local jobs and an upgrading of skills base of employment in the Newcastle region are just two of the possible outcomes,' the chairman of the Stock Exchange of Newcastle Limited, Mr John Tonkin, said. 'An electronic trading system at the Newcastle Stock Exchange would put local companies in contact with the many private and public sources of capital throughout Australia and internationally.' Although the Newcastle trading proposal is being considered for approval by the Australian Securities Commission, the Newcastle Stock Exchange itself is not a new idea. The exchange was first established in 1937 following a meeting of residents and has operated continuously from that date, except for 1940 to 1947 to enable members to enlist for World War II. On February 7, 1972, it was incorporated as a company with 13 members and during its heyday had up to 300 listed companies, ranging from local businesses to large national interests, but today the exchange is merely a group of four members trading among each other and through the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX) in Sydney. In its submission, the Stock Exchange of Newcastle Limited said it hoped to establish a new and innovative electronic trading system in Newcastle, to help companies raise capital and to allow investors to buy and sell securities in companies which were not catered for under the ASX's listing rules. The submission said the Newcastle Stock Exchange's rules had been rewritten to reflect current international standards, and predicted at least 25 companies could be listed in the proposed trading system's first six months of operation. On that note, there are a lot of companies in the Hunter who are just waiting for extra capital but do not have the ability to list on the major boards. By allowing this to operate, by allowing injections of capital, by allowing ventures to go ahead in the Hunter rather than going offshore, we will see those jobs created-very necessary jobs-that will bring unemployment in the Hunter region down perhaps to equity with that of the city areas, rather than being maintained at around three to four points higher than the cities.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker (Hon. N. M. Dondas)
theText: As I understand, from the clerk's advice,
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Bob Baldwin
theText: I will not dispute you on that. I will read it. It states:Thursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 11555 The reason that that has happened is this. After the very early shutdown days of BHP, it dropped from over 13,000 employees to under 3,000 under the former Labor governmentwithout a lot of input, without a lot of direction from the former government, whose only attempt to rectify that was the steel plan. And as we heard our great minister yesterday say in the House, and he has said it before, not one cent of the Button steel plan was invested in the Hunter. Not one cent was invested in the Hunter. But those people in the Hunter-their taxpayer dollars that were put into that steel plan-did not receive one benefit. The only benefit they have received is the unemployment benefits, as Labor st-ipped away over 10,000 jobs directly at BHP and many, many thousands more indirectly. we have that master of the pencil, the member for Corio( Mr O'Connor), who helped pencil the Button plan. I ask you: who has the interests of the Hunter at heart? We have. Why have we got them at heart? Because we are determined to deliver jobs; we are determined to deliver outcomes; we actually care for the people in the Hunter. Bill 1997 will bring about the demutualisation of the Australian Stock Exchange, involving conversiqn from a company limited by a guarantee to a company limited by shares. As a result, the concept of market access will be distinguished from the ownership of the ASX. In facilitating this demutualisation, the bill will also ensure that, in the ASX becoming a public company, its role as an industry regulator is not diminished or undermined. To achieve this, the bill provides for a number of limitations. Firstly, the responsibilities of the ASX as a self-regulatory organisation are clarified. Secondly, the bill provides that the Australian Securities Commission is to supervise the ASX's compliance with its own listing rules. Thirdly, the bill ensures that no-one can own or control more than five per cent of the shares in the ASX. Lastly, provision is made for the accountability of the ASX to the Australian Securities Commission and the government. . The ASX is owned, controlled by and run on behalf of its members under its own constitution and operating rules. Its membership is currently composed of the brokers who use the exchange to deal in the securities of businesses and governments. From its sometimes turbulent history, three clearly identifiable roles have emerged. It is a market regulator, commonly referred to as a self-regulatory organisation; it is a trade association which represents the interests of its members; and it is a commercial entity which operates a public securities market as a business. The ASX considers that its central purpose is 'to conduct markets in which investors and enterprises come together with confidence to create prosperity through the sharing of risks and rewards'. Accordingly, the ASX has come to play perhaps the pivotal role in Australia's capital markets. Specifically, it is the national exchange for the trading of the shares, notes, bonds and debentures of over 1,200 Australian and overseas companies and other entities. In the lead-up to its demutualisation, the ASX has had an extraordinarily successful period, particularly over the 1996-97 financial year. In that 12-month period, the value of foreign investments in Australian domestic equities rose by 15 per cent to $125 billion in the quarter ending March 1997. Capitalisation of the domestic market increased 27 per cent over the 199697 financial year to reach a record $444 billion at 30 June, comprising a 22 per cent rise in
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Hockey
theText: Who was that under?
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Bob Baldwin
theText: That was under both the Hawke and Keating governments. Then
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Hockey (North Sydney) (11.05 A.m.)
theText: The Corporations Law Amendment (ASX)11556 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 27 November 1997 the all-ordinaries index to a record level of 2725.9 points and new capital raising of $16.4 billion. As a percentage of Australia's GDP, the value of the ASX domestic market capitalisation reached a record 76 per cent, compared with just over 50 per cent 10 years ago. Turnover on the ASX from 1996-97 was also a record, at $212 billion. In the month of June, the average daily turnover exceeded $1 billion for the first time, and peak trading days exceeded $2 billion. The equities market, which is at the heart of the ASX's operations, was the 10th largest national equities market in the world last year. Equity transactions averaged over 20,000 a day, and the busiest single day saw over 36,000 transactions. The 12-month total was a staggering 5.39 million transactions. On a world scale, according to the Global Securities Consulting Services survey, the ASX ranked in the top three exchanges for operational risk, settlement services and value for money. At the close of the 1996-97 financial year, based on the average domestic market capitalisation, Australia had the third largest share market in South-East Asia. And to top off this spectacular year, the ASX's all-ordinaries and all-industrial indexes out-performed Japan's Topix and market-weighted index for South-East Asia. The ASX has not been complacent about its performances over the years. It has sought to further its gains by investing in technological advances, so much so that it is now in a position to offer outstanding service to its customers. Particularly noteworthy is the ASX plan to assist companies, from early 1998, to source informal equity finance on an Internet vehicle called the enterprise market. Basically, the enterprise market operates as a sophisticated financial dating service. Capital seekers, capital providers and venture capital intermediaries can be introduced in the one electronic space, therefore facilitating the development of venture capital as an established asset in Australia. The ASX has invested in superior technology systems, such as SEATS 97, the new trading platform for the equities market, and CLICK, an automated trading system to replace floor trading in the derivatives market, which together represent world best practice in trading technology. Yet, despite the exceptional performance of the ASX and its willingness to embrace innovation, it is an institution that is vulnerable to. competition, particularly of a global nature. This vulnerability of stock exchanges was not lost on the six state stock markets which amalgamated to form the ASX in 1987. They realised in the early 1980s that technological advances made them more vulnerable to competition and that an electronic market, which channelled orders from around Australia into one place, would provide the two most vital aspects of a stock exchange--optimum price discovery and maximised liquidity. This transformation marked the beginning of an increased adaptation to a changing environment. However, we now know that securities markets no longer recognise national boundaries. The mobility of investors and their capital, company listings, corporate structures, skilled labours and, potentially, stock exchanges have created global markets where players can, and do, cross borders in search of better operating conditions and those elusive dollars. Mr Deputy Speaker, you need no better example of that comment than the volatility in stock exchanges and in equity markets around the world in October, where we saw a massive flight to quality. At the end of the day, the Australian Stock Exchange can hold its head high over the way that it handled that volatility. Thursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 11557 The ASX faces challenges from other stock exchanges, which are engaged in trying to entice Australian businesses to their shores, as well as from the Internet, which will bring as yet untried share trading possibilities. But share market globalisation works both ways. Just as our ASX will have to watch its back, it will also have new opportunities for creating markets, attracting overseas investors and, importantly, forging regional alliances in the vein of the memorandums of understanding signed with the Jakarta and Surabaya stock exchanges. The ASX is well placed to meet the challenges presented by globalised markets head on. It is currently a financially sound institution which, after a decade, has not only a strong, positive cash flow, but net assets of around $158 million. Its markets have developed strongly over the past 10 years. The value of trading grew from a daily average of $264 million in June 1987 to a remarkable $1.14 billion in June 1997. The derivatives market experienced a similar rate of growth, from under three million options contracts in 1986-87 to just over 10 million in the 1996-97 period. The capitalisation of the equities market rose at a rate faster than the economy as a whole. Equity capital raisings have averaged $15 billion a year over the past five years, with new issues far exceeding new floats. This decade of growth and diversification in the Australian Stock Exchange has also been distinguished by unprecedented demutualisations of large insurance companies and the privatisation of key government owned institutions. One of the most successful floats has undoubtedly been the recent Telstra IPO, which now boasts 1.8 million shareholders-so successful that the federal government originally under-estimated the total sale value by nearly one-half. At this point, I would like to offer my congratulations to the Minister for Finance and Administration ( Mr Fahey) who has done an outstanding job. John Fahey has laid his-hands, in a way that can only be described as an outstanding achievement, on the most significant IPO in Australia's history. I would join with this House in congratulating the minister on what has been the most successful IPO in the world this year. Privatisation of various government institutions has also resulted in phenomenal share subscriptions, as we recently saw. The Commonwealth Bank now has over 370,000 shareholders, the GIO Australia 100,000, and Qantas 105,000. Shareholdings in demutualised insurance mutuals are just as remarkable. The National Mutual has some 500,000 shareholders and Colonial Mutual 460,000 shareholders. Soon the AMP will be listing with over one million shareholders and a significant number of those shareholders, particularly through demutualisation, are first time investors. Running in tandem with this change in trading focus has been a readjustment in the compilation of consumer shareholders so astounding that today 4.7 million Australians directly own shares, compared to only 1.5 million in 1987. Indeed, the mums and dads of Australia are snapping up blue-chip listings like a shark pursuing a school of fish through muddied watersshareholdings in demutualised insurance enterprises and privatised government institutions, the mums and dads of Australia have staked their claims in publicly listed companies such as the National Australia Bank, now with over 240,000 shareholders, Woolworths with 251,000, and BHP with 300,000 shareholders. And of course, it is not insignificant that of the 1.8 million Telstra shareholders, 600,000 or more are first-time investors.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Sawford
theText: 'Shark' is the operative word.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Hockey
theText: and I will attribute that to Dave Brockhoff. In addition to large11558 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 27 November 1997 The 1997 Australian share ownership survey revealed that 20 per cent of Australian adults, approximately 2.2 million Australians, now have direct investments in ASX listed equities. And after the Telstra float, that figure is 2.8 million and it will, of course, be even higher after the demutualisation of the AMP. In addition, the average value of private investors' portfolios has risen from $26,000 in 1994 to $33,000 today. Sigriificantly, these figures are not too dissimilar from those of the United Kingdom and Canada and, of course, the United Kingdom has had the most significant and successful privatisation program in the OECD world. These survey results suggest that private investors directly owned about $86 billion in equities at the end of May 1997. The fact that nearly 40 per cent of the Australian shareholders have a yearly household income of less than $50,000; that nearly one-third of all 25to 34year-olds own shares; that there has been a significant increase in share ownership amongst women, which is particularly pleasing-they now constitute almost one-third of all share investors-and that the dominance of older people in the share market has declined, flies in the face of the old-time perception that the stock market is merely a playground for the rich. On the contrary, these figures suggest the dawning of a new age in share market ownership. The Australian public has flocked to the floating of enterprises which have stood the test of time, weathering the good times with the bad. But there is yet another factor which has impacted on the decision by members of the ASX to demutualise, and that is the effect of trading on the Internet. This takes globalisation of world markets one step further, adding both an air of uncertainty and anticipation to global trading. In July 1996, it was estimated that Australians represented approximately one million of the 60 million individuals with access to the Internet, making Australia the fourth largest country of Internet users worldwide. If analysts are correct, by 2000 there could be between 500 million and 800 million Internet users worldwide, and over one billion by 2005. What this means for global trading is mind-boggling. The concept that Australians will be buying and selling shares from the comfort of their living rooms is very real. And it is into this environment that the ASX plans to forge its future as a demutualised institution, an institution with a proud 126-year history which, from its first amalgamation through to its adoption of the latest technology, has proven itself to be adaptable and progressive. In short, it is an institution whose publicly listed shares will be devoured by the Australian public. The decision to demutualise the ASX shows great discernment on the part of its current members. The pressures of increasingly globalised trading, which have brought competition across borders, coupled with the desire of the Australian public to own a piece of established Australian institutions, has meant that a change in direction for the ASX could not have been more timely. This demutualisation is a magnificent opportunity for the strengths of the ASX to be shared among the people of Australia in addition to furthering, in the words of the Treasurer ( Mr Costello) 'the reputation of Australia's capital markets as among the best in the world'. The demutualised ASX will combine with our stable economy, our low inflation and a government clearly committed to substantial taxation reform to encourage further foreign investment and therefore the creation of even more jobs in Australia. At this point, I would like to offer my very sincere congratulations to the pioneering efforts of the chairman of the ASX, Maurice Newman, to the managing director of the ASX, Mr Thursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITIEE 11559 Richard Humphry, and to the board and to all the members of the Australian Stock Exchange. They have led the Stock Exchange through this very difficult period because they have a vision for the Stock Exchange which means that demutualisation is the first step towards Australia having an even more successful stock exchange in the world markets. I commend the Corporations Law Amendment (ASX) Bill 1997 to the House as an example of yet another great Australian institution ready to meet the challenges of an increasingly globalised economy and the desire of the Australian public to be a part of this future. debate. The Australian share market and the Australian Stock Exchange are very important to the people of Australia. This was indicated most obviously during the recent Telstra float, which was four times oversubscribed when the mums and dads of Australia showed that they wanted to participate in part ownership of a major national company. The result of the Telstra one-third sale will mean that Australia could well become the country in the world which has the largest percentage of share ownership amongst its popUlation. I believe the Labor Party stands condemned for not supporting the one-third sale of Telstra, and personally I hope that the coalition goes to the next election seeking a mandate from the people to sell more of this important national company. The government has always said that it would not sell any more than one-third of Telstra without a further mandate from the Australian people. I believe the fact that we will have 1.8 or 1.9 million shareholders in this company indicates that there is a demand there-four times oversubscribed-and that it would be appropriate for the government to consider floating more of this important national company. The purpose of the Corporations Law Amendment (ASX) Bill 1997 is to facilitate the demutualisation of the Australian Stock exchange. This will mean that, like many other Australian companies, it will seek to be a mutual company and that it will become a public company limited by shares with external ownership and operated for profit. The government is not seeking to impose this demutualisation; this is the result of a decision made by the members of the Australian Stock Exchange themselves. Everyone knows what an important role the Australian Stock Exchange plays in Australia's capital markets. In fact there are three aspects to its role within the securities industry. Firstly, it is a market regulator; secondly, it is a commercial entity conducting a public securities market as a business; and, thirdly, it is a trade association representing the interests of its members. I believe this legislation, when carried, will facilitate the carrying out of the role that the Australian Stock Exchange has performed in Australia over a very large number of years. The ASX is the front-line operator of the day-to-day operations of the stock market. In making and administering the listing rules regulating listed companies, it occupies a formal, statutorily recognised position in the system of co-regulation of companies and securities with the Australian Securities Commission. The ASX is currently organised and governed in a manner that is traditional for stock exchanges. As I said, this bill seeks to tum it from a mutual company into a public company limited by shares, but in effect it is presently a cooperative owned and controlled by members and run on behalf of its members under its own constitution and operating rules. As has been indicated by other speakers, members are the brokers who use the exchange to deal in the securities of businesses and governments. I believe it was a very forward-thinking action by
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Slipper (Fisher) (11.21 A.m.)
theText: I am very pleased to be able to participate in this11560 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 27 November 1997 the members of the Australian Stock Exchange to effectively ask the government to bring this legislation into effect so that the Australian Stock Exchange will be well placed to face the challenges of the new millennium. The bill will facilitate the proposed changes to the ASX's governance arrangements while at the same time ensure that the role of the ASX in the regulatory framework is not diminished or impaired as a result of its conversion to a public company. It is very important that the current overwhelming confidence that the Australian people have in the Australian Stock Exchange is maintained. This will be achieved in a number of ways. Firstly, the bill clarifies the responsibilities of the ASX as a self-regulatory organisation and ensures appropriate accountability of the ASX to the ASC and the government in carrying out its SRO responsibilities. Secondly, the bill will limit persons and their associates, both Australian and those from overseas, to owning and controlling no more than five per cent of the shares in the ASX. That is very important considering the key role that the ASX currently plays. The five per cent limit can be contrasted with the current individual limit on bank ownership of 10 per cent. That lower percentage shows that the government is very serious about making sure that there is a dispersed share ownership of the Australian Stock Exchange following the passage of this bill. Another important thing that the bill does is provide that the Australian Securities Commission will supervise the compliance by the ASX with the listing rules in respect of its own listing, the listing of the ASX. That is very important, and I know other speakers have highlighted the fact that this is a vital safeguard. The bill also recognises the altered relationship of the ASX with brokers and clarifies the point that the ASX continues to be responsible for the conduct and integrity of market participants in trading on the ASX and in related activities. Efficient capital markets are absolutely essential to the government's objective of achieving higher economic growth. Most people in the community would accept that we have done a very good job there. Our predictions of growth are likely to be fulfilled, despite the currency crises which have swept across some of the nations to our north. Efficient capital markets are also essential to our objective of facilitating private sector investment, employment generation and wealth creation. The Australian Stock Exchange plays a central role in the efficient operation of the Australian economy. That was why, when this legislation was being looked at, it was absolutely essential to niake sure that it was balanced legislation and that the safeguards that are included in the bill were in fact included. The ASX is too important to Australia to risk undermining the essential role it plays and the confidence that people have in it. As I said earlier, the vital role of the ASX was highlighted by the way it handled the Telstra float. The honourable member for North Sydney( Mr Hockey) was generous in congratulating the Minister for Finance and Administration ( Mr Fahey), and I would like to join him in congratulating the minister on what I believe was an absolutely outstanding job. There will be a very large boost to the Australian share market as a result of the Telstra float. The honourable member for North Sydney also referred to the coming demutualisation of the AMP Society which will see about another one million shareholders added to the share market. That follows the demutualisation of both the National Mutual life office and the Thursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 11561 Colonial Mutual life office. So this bill which will demutualise the ASX really is very much in line with actions taken by other important national institutions. Australian share ownership is currently at 22 per cent and indirect share ownership at 36 per cent. As I said, after the sale of one-third of Telstra and after the demutualisation of the AMP, we will find that Australians will have maybe the highest level of share ownership of any country in the world. While the Labor Party, with respect to most legislation brought into the parliament, usually likes to look back 10, 20 or even 30 years, it is, on this occasion, supporting the bill, and I commend the Labor Party for that. I believe it is vital that parliamentarians join together when legislation has widespread acceptance in the community. The fact that both sides of politics are supporting the bill is an indication of the importance of the bill, and the benefits that it will bring to the Australian Stock Exchange and to the Australian share market. It is obvious that having an up-to-date, well-run and efficient stock exchange is essential, particularly when one looks at the recent market correction which took place in this country and when one looks at the diminution in the value of shares in other countries throughout the world. This bill is all about encouraging the ongoing, efficient role of the Australian Stock Exchange for the next century. It is a mature stock exchange. We have a mature market and we are a very mature country. Demutualisation is, I believe, a sign that the Australian Stock Exchange has grown up and it is an important step in facilitating an appropriate role for the ASX in the 21st century. This is an important piece of legislation because it will ensure that there is a more effective and appropriate corporate structure. This will enhance the competitiveness of the Australian Stock Exchange and the Australian capital markets domestically and internationally. It brings into effect the overwhelmingly expressed wishes of the current members of the Australian Stock Exchange, and it brings about something that the ASX needs-that is, a more flexible corporate structure because of the likelihood of increased competition between the ASX, the SFE, and other emerging Australian exchanges, should some of the Wallis recommendations and other reforms under the government's current corporate law economic reform program be implemented. Some people have wondered whether the ASX, as a public for-profit company, can legitimately continue its role of effective surveillance and regulation of the market. In response, it ought to be noted that it will be in the interests of the Australian Stock Exchange to maintain the integrity of the market and the stringent regulation of its listing rules. The market would detect any lapse of standards and this naturally would have an adverse impact concerning investment and listings. I have pointed out that the ASX will not be responsible for the regulation of its own listing, that this will be carried out by the ASC. It is important not only that the right thing be done but also that it be seen to be done. This is a vital provision. The government will also clarify the ASX as a self-regulatory organisation in ensuring the honesty and integrity of the securities market for which it is responsible, and will make improvements where necessary to the regulatory framework governing the conduct of public stock markets. Some people have said that the ASX might use this opportunity to charge higher prices. But it ought to be noted that the ASX is already subject to competition and presently it has the capacity to increase charges for the services it provides. This would continue whether or not it demutualises. In any event, the market will playa very important role in ensuring that costs are kept to a reasonable level because the ASX would certainly not, as a publicly listed 11562 MAIN COMMITIEE Thursday, 27 November 1997 company, want to be losing business to overseas exchanges or to competing exchanges in this country. Some people may have said that there are no foreign ownership controls but the government has covered that by pointing out that no individual would be able to own more than 5 per cent of the Australian Stock Exchange as a publicly listed company. This is balanced legislation which prepares the Australian Stock Exchange for the next century. It is legislation which is strongly supported by the current members of the Australian Stock Exchange, and it is legislation that is backed by both sides of the parliament. It is good, sound legislation and I am very pleased that it will be receiving the overwhelming support of this chamber. I commend the bill to the committee. Corporations Law Amendment (AS X) Bill and join with the previous speaker, the honourable member for Fisher( Mr Slipper), in congratulating the House on the bipartisan approach to this quite revolutionary development that will be happening to the Australian Stock Exchange. the responsibilities of the ASX as a self-regulatory organisation and ensuring appropriate accountability of the Australian Stock Exchange to the ASC and to the government in carrying out its self-regulatory organisational responsibilities; limiting persons and their associates, Australian and foreign, to owning or controlling no more than five per cent of the shares in the Australian Stock Exchange; and providing that the ASC supervises the ASX's compliance with its listing rules in respect of the ASX's own proposed listing. But the evolution of this bill, the Corporations Law Amendment (ASX) Bill 1997 has occurred so that the nexus between the ownership of the Stock Exchange and the access to the share market will be broken. The ownership of the Australian Stock Exchange will be open to anyone who wishes to buy its shares while access to the markets will also be available. The principal reason why Australian Stock Exchange members recommended that the government make amendments to the Corporations Law Amendment (ASX) Bill 1997 was because the financial market and the global environment that we are in have changed quite significantly and have brought new challenges to the Australian Stock Exchange. There have been structural changes, particularly with the globalisation of financial markets and crossborder competition of listing, trading and competition within Australia. One of the principal reasons why it needs to be demutualised is that the Australian Stock Exchange needs funds路 for further capital expansion. Why? Because of the increasing competition of globalisation and the necessity to have new technology and communication. Likewise, in the past where governments have been barriers of control, they are no longer, particularly when it comes to exchange rates or to the flow of capital, so further assistance is needed to the ASX particularly to raise capital. Institutional investors can also move money anywhere and cross-border activities amount to over $6 trillion. Therefore it is essential that we hold on to our local companies and we need a more flexible approach while attracting foreign companies to have either listings or joint listings on the Australian Stock Exchange. With the advent of new technology, more sophisticated computer hardware and software will be needed to meet the challenges in the future. In the last decade the Australian Stock
title: Representatives Main Commitiee

speaker: Mr Anthony (Richmond) (11.34 A.m.)
theText: I rise to support the government on the
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Slipper
theText: Evolutionary.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Anthony
theText: Evolutionary, as well. The main features of the draft bill are clarifyingThursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 11563 Exchange spent over $120 million. The funding for this came from the Securities Institute Development Account, SIDA, and the National Guarantee Fund, NGF. However, in this new environment of low interest rates and the requirements for higher margin calls and deposits and with the advent of more sophisticated derivatives-and of course there is added competition now with the Australian Stock Exchange against the SFE-higher surplus funds will no longer be as available as they have been in the past for expanding new technologies that are necessary to maintain our competitive edge and indeed to increase it, particularly to North Asia. Therefore, the Australian Stock Exchange must generate more of its own funds to replace existing hardware and software systems. The bottom line that was principally behind this key decision to demutualise was to raise further finance.
