Thus the Corporations Law needed to be amended because the corporations laws at present do not permit a company limited by guarantee to change its structure to a company limited by shares, which is exactly the status for all other companies listed on the Australian Stock Exchange. That came from the ASE research information paper. . Members should also understand that the Australian Stock Exchange is the central facilitator for Australian capital markets and provides a vital role in the allocation of savings of Australians to productive capital investment. Clearly this is what was demonstrated recently with the listing of Telstra. One of the other driving forces behind the demutualisation decision was that the Australian Stock Exchange has a very unusual balance sheet and over 80 per cent of the financial assets are in cash. Quite frankly this is not an appropriate structure for the future for this type of organisation as it competes against other global exchanges to attract capital-although the Australian Stock Exchange has had a tremendous track record to date. Certainly, looking back over the past 10 years, in the market capitalisation of early 1986-87 when I worked in the equities market myself, domestic equities were $184 billion. That figure today has gone to over $444 billion in domestic equities or market capitalisation. When you include the overseas equities in 1986-87, which was a very small $42 billion, that figure has now gone to $290 billion. In total, we have seen a rise in market capitalisation from the mid1980s from $226 billion to over $734 billion. That is a great credit to the Australian Stock Exchange. An interesting factor, though, is that the actual number of listed companies has decreased from the early 1986-87 figure of 1,320 to just under 1,200 today. We have seen huge numbers of mergers and takeovers-and, obviously, companies that have not complied to ASX have been delisted-and we have seen a far more transparent and fair regulatory environment, which was very different to the 1980s, where the corporate cowboys were evident wherever you looked. In actual equity raising, there has been a massive increase in equity raising this year of over $16 billion. We have seen record turnovers and record participation of Australians in equity ownership: from 22 per cent, as mentioned by the previous speaker, up to 36 per cent indirectly-which is very different from where Australia was at 10 or even 15 years ago. At the current rate, we could well surpass the United States, particularly, which has one of the highest equity participation ratios.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Slipper
theText: It is almost certain.11564 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 27 November 1997 purpose of the bill is to enable the conversion of the Australian Stock Exchange to a public company. The Australian Stock Exchange, as mentioned, is presently a company limited by guarantee and, therefore, the liability of its members is limited to the respective amounts that the members undertake to contribute to the property of the company if it is wound up. This really is obsolete in this age. Contrast this with companies limited by shares, with the liability of members being limited to any amount which is unpaid on their shares. Each member currently in the Australian Stock Exchange has an equal interest in the company; therefore it is termed a mutual organisation. That is why it is being demutualised. This decision was reached on 22 October 1996, where the members of the Australian Stock Exchange voted 540 to 22 to demutualise-which was quite extraordinary, because they actually had tried to do this a number of times in the past, but were not able to reach the magical 75 per cent of membership approval. Thus the ASX will be converting from a company limited by guarantee to a company limited by shares. As I mentioned before, the Australian Stock Exchange plays a vital role in facilitating the trading of securities in listed companies and performs a regulatory role through the use of its listing rules and its ultimate power to delist a company. Certainly, there have been concerns that the Australian Securities Commission may eventually absorb most of ASX's regulatory functions. We will have to wait and see. Indications are at this stage that most of those functions will remain with the Australian Stock Exchange-with, of course, the exemption of its own listing. The main provisions in the bill, in proposed sections 766E to 7661, have the effect of prohibiting any person from being entitled to more than five per cent of the voting shares in the Australian Stock Excr .nge. There has been much debate over why the Australian Stock Exchange has such a low limit, particularly when compared with foreign companies, who are limited at 15 per cent; with banks, at 10 per cent; and indeed with casinos, which have to have regulatory approval to go above five per cent. I believe there is very strong justification-even though it might fly in the face of having an availability to move up to higher holdings in capital markets-for it to be essential that the ASX has a very broad diversity of ownership so that no particular institution can gain control of the ASX, which is obviously one of the main facilitators for capital in Australia. And it is in the public interest that no individual person gain control of the ASX. So there are very good reasons why the government has decided to limit the level to five per cent, and I am encouraged to see that the opposition also endorses that. The other principal reason, of course, is that it becomes more liquid. This is particularly important. We certainly do not want to see foreign companies having any further control, particularly in an environment where it is very competitive amongst the New York Stock Exchange, Tokyo, London, or, of course, the new developing markets in Asia. The other proposed section is 769A to 769D, and they are concerned with the Australian Stock Exchange ensuring that each stock market of the exchange is an orderly and fair market and that there are adequate arrangements for monitoring and enforcing compliance. Part of this comes down to the actual administrative and voting structure of the new demutualised stock exchange. There will not be a requirement, as there has been in the past, for decisions to be made where there has to be 75 per cent in favour of a decision. It was very difficult to reach that, because the ownership to date has been by stockbrokers.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Anthony
theText: Certainly, with the demutualisation of the AMP, this will happen. TheThursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITIEE 11565 What will happen now with regard to the decision making ability of the Australian Stock Exchange after demutualisation is that there will be a board that will be principally making those decisions. Those decisions can be made more rapidly and be more relevant to what is happening with public companies today. As you look towards the future of the Australian Stock Exchange, it has had a tremendous growth rate. We have managed to obtain enormous amounts of capital internally through a number of public listings such as Telstra. This has seen a rapid increase in share ownership across Australia; we have also seen the demutualisation of other organisations, particularly Colonial, National Mutual and, of course, the big one, AMP, which will be, potentially, quite revolutionary: over another million shareholders could enter the market. By demutualising and becoming more modem, the Australian Stock Exchange will have an ability to raise capital, because it has a limited balance sheet now. Its balance sheet can become more flexible, and decision making can be made more appropriately. We can maintain our competitive edge, but, more importantly, be a beacon to continue to attract foreign listings onto the Australian Stock Exchange to路 develop new and more sophisticated derivatives markets-for which the ASX have been leaders, along with the Sydney Futures Exchangeand, likewise, capitalise on the uncertainty that is happening now to our northern neighbours in South-East Asia and also to north Asia. With a number of scandals that have been happening for many years now in Japan-one of their largest security houses, Yam aichi , potentially going into liquidation-with their banking system, there is a great advantage for Australia, for the Australian Securities Exchange, and for financial markets to stake out a much bigger claim in Asia. There is also the benefit of the time zone that we are in and our transparency. The other advantages we have are a very sophisticated IT industry and a transparent financial system and these can be used to the advantage of the Australian Securities Exchange. In conclusion, I endorse the move to have the Corporations Law Amendment Bill amended to take into account the demutualisation of the Australian Stock Exchange. It has done a terrific job-so has the chairman, I might add, Maurice Newman-and I do believe that the next decade will be an exciting decade. We are leading the way for this demutualisation. There have been other exchanges which have not gone to full demutualisation, for example Stockholm, and there are three other exchanges in Europe. This is a new frontier amongst capital markets, but if we lead the way then there are other markets and other availabilities that we might be able to trade on. I congratulate ASX and also the House for its bipartisan support of this bill. a.m.)-in reply-I would just like to thank those people who have participated in the debate. As the member for Richmond( Mr Anthony) has said, it has been a bipartisan debate in regard to support for this going ahead with the changes with the Australian Stock Exchange. There are a few comments which I would like to make. First of all, the member for Wills( Mr Kelvin Thomson), the only member who spoke from the opposition, quoted some figures in regard to the Australian Stock Exchange annual report, claiming that there have been large falls in the Australian Stock Exchange funding. WhatI can say to you-I cannot give you the exact figures-is that the figures quoted in the Australian Stock Exchange annual report for the Australian securities budget are incorrect. I just want to put that on the record. While there
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Miles (Braddon
theText: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister) (11.4811566 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 27 November 1997 has been some reduction in the funding of the ASC, it is nowhere near the reduction quoted in the ASX's annual report. The government is confident that the ASC will be able to make the necessary efficiencies to continue to meet its regulatory functions and responsibilities within the reduced budget. The member for Wills also made comments relating to the issue of public confidence in the Australian stock exchange in the context of allegations that different shareholders may be treated differently in the allocation of shares in popular floats. It would be inappropriate to discuss specifically the circumstances of particular allegations made today. Those are matters for the ASC as the independent statutory regulator of the markets. Let me say that I think there is a constant theme from some people in the opposition to play personality politics rather than policy politics, and this was a classic example of that here today. It is just personality politics rather than a case of getting on with the debate of the issue at hand. I will however make a number of general points in reply. The bill will impose a specific obligation on the Australian Stock Exchange in paragraph 769A(i)(c) to have adequate arrangements for the expulsion, supervision and the disciplining of a member for conduct inconsistent with just and equitable principles in the transaction of business. The bill is also concerned that the co-regulatory arrangements of the ASX and the ASC continue to ensure the appropriate regulation of the market and the activities of participants in that market. The amendments proposed to be made to the Corporations Law will impose on the ASX specific obligations to conduct a fair and orderly market. The operations of the ASX and its market will, as of now, be oversighted in the first instance by the ASC under the memorandum of understanding moved by the ASC and the ASX. The memorandum of understanding deals with three or four points. Firstly, with reference to the membership and the oversight of brokers, this MOU sets out agreed arrangements for promoting cooperation in monitoring, surveillance and enforcement action in relation to ASX members. It details procedures that the ASX will undertake in its surveillance of ASX members, and provides for the referral of serious matters concerning the conduct of ASX members to the ASC. Secondly, with regard to market trading and referrals, this MOU provides for the referral of serious matters by the ASX to the ASC. Serious matters include: market manipulation, insider trading, and warehousing. Thirdly, it deals with the surveillance and monitoring of compliance by listed companies with the disclosure, accounting and corporate governance requirements of the ASX listing rules, and certain parts of the Corporations Law. In the event that the ASC were to have concerns with the operations of the ASX and its market, it would furnish appropriate advice to the minister. The minister will have the power to issue a directive to the ASX requiring it to do specified things that the minister believes will promote compliance by the ASX with the ongoing obligations imposed on it. If the ASX failed to comply with that directive, the ASC may apply to the court for an order that the ASX does so comply. In the light of these arrangements-as a rebuttal to the comments made by the member for Wills in that area-the government does not thus anticipate any fall in public confidence in the operations of the Australian Stock Exchange, and we are totally confident that these arrangements are satisfactory. Once again I thank all of those people who participated in the debate and I commend the bill to the House. Thursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 11567 Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.A. Crosio)-If no member wishes to consider the bill in detail, I will put the report question forthwith. The question is that this bill be reported to the House without amendment. Question resolved in the affirmative. White Paper on Foreign and Trade Policy Debate resumed from 20 November, on motion by Mr Downer: That the House take note of the paper. on this important white paper some three months after the document was brought into the parliament with the announcement that this. represented the coming of age of our foreign policy. AllI can say is that it has taken an awfully long time for its coming before the parliament, although it was, I admit, discussed last week in this committee. At the outset can I say that the background against which this paper was produced and commissioned was a raft of policy bungles that have upset our neighbours and trading partners, and that such a paper was necessary to try to give some appearance of coherence and direction to our foreign policy. I will just instance some of those policy bungles. Soon after the government came into office we had the abolition of DIFF, the Development Import Finance Facility, which caused great upset to a number of our trading partners in Asia, especially China, Indonesia and the Philippines, particularly through the way it was handled. Then we caused further upset to China by the government's portrayal of the annual Ausmin security talks with the United States last year as a 'reinvigoration' of the alliance. China interpreted that as the alliance being directed against it, so souring its relations with Australia and the United States. Then there was major concern created in Asian countries by the racist statement to the House last September by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). Of course, the government was not to blame for that, but it was very much to blame for the fact that it was not until eight months later that the Prime Minister( Mr Howard) repudiated, in unambiguous terms, those remarks. The fact that there was that delay caused deep scars in our relationship with Asian countries. In particular, the whole incident has reawakened Asian stereotype thinking about Australia as a white supremacy, racist nation-a notion of Australia that we had, with much success, been endeavouring to bury over the last 25 years. Nothing this government has done has been -ore damaging to Australia than its eight months of wilful silence on this most important Issue. Then we had the issue in the United Nations last October where we were humiliated by a defeat by Portugal for a seat on the Security Council. Of course, the factors I have just been referring to were not unimportant in that outcome. Then, just a few months ago, we had the appalling incident at the South Pacific finance ministers meeting in Cairns, with the careless handling of an extraordinarily graphic, no holds barred, background briefing on South Pacific nations and their leaders. Its subsequent reporting in the press created a major embarrassment and caused deep offence to our South Pacific neighbours, which was made much worse by
title: Representatives Main Commitiee

speaker: Mr Willis (Gellibrand) (11.55 A.m.)
theText: I welcome the opportunity to make some comments11568 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 27 November 1997 the refusal of the Treasurer ( Mr Costello) to apologise. Altogether, this was one of the most gauche episodes in Australian diplomatic history. Then, in October, we again alienated our South Pacific neighbours at the South Pacific Forum conference in the Cook Islands, at which Australia's uncompromising position on greenhouse gases had us apparently isolated 15 to 1. Not even New Zealand was reported as supporting us. Certainly, the greenhouse gas issue is a difficult issue for Australia, but not just for us. Faced with nations which would be drowned by a couple of metres rise in the sea level, we appeared unsympathetic and self-interested. Altogether, our relations with our South Pacific neighbours must路 now be at about as Iowan ebb as at any time since Queenslanders were kidnapping South Pacific islanders to work as slaves in their canefields. Furthermore, we also have the current issue before the parliament of the Native Title Act, with the appearance of us engaging in action which is a breach of our own Racial Discrimination Act in taking a racist position, ,an action which is being noted overseas and again embarrassing us on the international scene. A good indication of how Australia stands in international circles was provided by the recent comments of a leading international figure-himself an Australian, born and bred-Jim Wolfensohn, the President of the World Bank. He praised Australia for its reaching out to Asia through its leadership in APEC, the ASEAN consultative group and the work we did in Cambodia-all, of course, Labor initiatives. But then he went on to express his concerns about Australia's current leadership and whether it had the courage and belief to lead Australia to take advantage of the great opportunities provided by its geography and innate capacities. This is the context in which the white paper has to be seen, a context of extraordinary blunders and serious policy mistakes and the international perception of a government that is unsure about Asia and lacking in courage and belief to be fully involved with it. This white paper is clearly an attempt to put some coherence and substance into what had become a policy shambles. The best one can say for it is that it was sorely needed, but it will require much more than this pedestrian document to restore Australia's international standing. The document is called In the national interest: Australia's foreign and trade policy which begs the question: what is the national interest? The document answers that question in this way. On page (iii), it says: Preparing for the future is a not matter of grand constructs. It is about the hard-headed pursuit of the interests which lie at the core of foreign and trade policy: the security of the Australian nation and the jobs and standard of living of the Australian people. That was a definition of the security of the national interests. There is no argument that ensuring national security and enhancing employment and living standards should be key objectives for our foreign affairs and trade policy. However, the Minister for Foreign Affairs( Mr Downer) went so far as to say that this was the jobs foreign and trade policy. If he wants to call it the jobs policy and have it measured on that basis, he has got an appalling problem, because the jobs record of this government, compared with that of the previous government, is quite appalling. Perhaps more importantly in this context, in the definition of the national interests, it seems extraordinarily insular to say that these factors of national security, employment and living standards are the only factors that comprise our national interests. What about our obligations to be a good international citizen? To be concerned about such matters as world health problems, world environmental problems, the international drug trade, the poverty of three Thursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 11569 billion people living on $2 per day or less, the need to promote human rights around the world, the need to promote the rights of women, children, indigenous populations et cetera: are these not matters that concern the national interest? Certainly, the narrow and, one could say, selfish approach of the white paper forms an interesting contrast with the policy declarations of the previous Labor government, which were spelt out in very substantial terms in the book Australia's Foreign Relations by the previous Foreign Minister Mr Gareth Evans and Mr Bruce Grant, in which the third leg of being a good international citizen was given great prominence. . It also makes an interesting comparison to look at the new Labor government in Britain and the way in which it defines its role. They issued a mission statement by Robin Cook, the Foreign Secretary, on 12 May, soon after coming into office. And this is how it read at the start: The Mission of the Foreign and Commonwealth Office is to promote the national interests of the United Kingdom and to contribute to a strong world community. We shall pursue that Mission to secure for Britain four benefits through our policy: Then they go on to security and prosperity. Under the heading, 'Quality of Life', it says: We shall work with others to protect the World's environment and to counter the menace of drugs, terrorism and crime; Under 'Mutual Respect' it says: We shall work through international forms and bilateral relationships to spread the values of human rights, civil liberties and democracy which we demand for ourselves. So they put these other issues of being good international citizens right up there, up frollt with the other issues of security and prosperity for the British people. The contrast with this white paper is quite marked. The paper does go on to discuss some national values briefly, in a low-key secondary way, and in that regard it does give a quite unambiguous rejection of racial discrimination and commitment to racial equality, and that was very welcome. Indeed, it should have been said straight after the speech of the member for Oxley in September of last year. Apart from racial equality, no other human right is specifically mentioned. The paper heavily emphasises the need for a pragmatic approach to promoting human rights. Perhaps we are seeing what this pragmatic approach means in operation in China where, after we had alienated China, as I mentioned earlier, we then sought to get back into China's good books by refusing to support a resolution condemning China's human rights abuses at the UN human rights convention earlier this year, a resolution traditionally supported by Australia. When the Prime Minister visited China, discussion on human rights was hived off for secret talks between officials. As far as I am aware, there is no public indication of the nature and extent of those discussions, except for a report in the Financial Review of 28 August of this year, in an article by Paul Monk headed, 'Beijing's deadly secrets'. In talking about these secret discussions, he said: Since the dialogue is to be secret, it is hard to know what its terms of reference are to be. We may gather something of its character, however, from the fact that the Chinese Government has announced that political prisoners are not under discussion, because of course, "China does not have any political prisoners". 11570 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 27 November 1997. If that is an indication of the nature of these discussions, we cannot expect too much to be coming from them. In other words, it would be a very pragmatic approach to human rights indeed. ' In relation to the economy, the white paper places great stress on the importance of opening up our economy to international markets and to economic integration with Asia, and it is absolutely right to do that. The Minister for Foreign Affairs correctly points to the extraordinary development in our economic links with the Asia-Pacific region in the last 15 years or so, but he fails to say that this has happened mostly as a result of the previous Labor government's initiatives. I refer to such things as the development of a much more competitive economy; the major reductions in tariffs set in place under Labor; the establishment of APEC, which was a Labor idea; the APEC leaders conference, which was the idea of Prime Minister Paul Keating; and the Bogar declaration, which Labor was instrumental in initiating and which sets the scene for further tariff reductions throughout the region. All of these initiatives endorsed by the white paper are very much Labor initiatives. ' The white paper essentially commits to processes started by Labor: the continuance of APEC and the pursuance of the Bogor declaration to bring that to fruition. It notes that Australia has already reduced tariffs and other barriers more than most other APEC member countriessomething which Labor put in place. As for the future, it states that the government will take account of what other governments are doing in deciding future steps. That is a position that Labor articulated well before the government adopted that policy approach. Finally, the white paper's assessment regarding the most profound influences on Australia's foreign and trade policies over the next 15 years refers to globalisation and the continuing economic rise of East Asia. It states on page v at paragraph 17: The Government's judgment is that economic growth in industrialising East Asia will continue at relatively high levels over the next fifteen years. That may well be right as a long-term judgment, but in the shortto medium-term it appears increasingly like a wrong call. Even before the white paper was published, events were occurring in Asia which might have led to some caution, but since then the unfolding array of crashes in currency markets, stock markets, property markets and financial institutions in East Asia have increasingly undermined the white paper's assessment. At least in the short term, for the next one or two years, East Asian growth is certainly going to be considerably reduced by all these aspects. It will vary between the countries, but certainly in Thailand, South Korea and probably Indonesia, growth is going to be drastically reduced, if not put into recession, and certainly growth in other countries will be significantly impaired. In the light of all that, one would have to conclude that this is a potentially very serious development. President Clinton, at the APEC leaders meeting currently occurring in Vancouver said that we now have a global crisis. Given that East Asia accounted for 40 per cent of world economic growth in 1996, a dramatic slowing in the growth of this region-which now appears certain-must impact upon the whole world. With 60 per cent of Australia's exports in the region, we must expect that they will be substantially affected, with both reduced volumes and prices. But in addition, we must expect a flood of imports from East Asian countries whose prices will now be much more competitive in Australian dollars. And as their domestic economies languish, there will be great pressure on them to expand exports to obtain some form of economic growth. So for us that means Thursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 11571 rapidly rising imports, great pressure on our import competing industries and a substantially deteriorating current account. It also means reduced growth. The Treasurer said that it would be barely measurable, but the OECD has already said that the GDP growth reduction for Australia would be about 0.4 per cent in 1998 and that in other countries it would be up to about three-quarters of a per cent-and all that was before South Korea was in the hands of the IMF. So for the next couple of years-hopefully no longer than that-our extensive integration with East Asia is likely to mean that we will wear some substantial economic pain, more so than most other developed Western countries which are not so integrated. It would be a great tragedy, however, if that led us to go back on our commitment to trade liberalisation. This is a short-term issue for us. We should not let it distract us from the long-term benefits of trade liberalisation. We should keep our eyes on the longer gain, and there will be long-term benefits as East Asia gets back on its growth path. (Time expired) the committee will note the white paper In the national interest: Australia'sforeign and trade policy, published recently by the government. It is a visionary document and a document which should enjoy bipartisan support. Foreign policy in Australia has been a bipartisan matter, largely, and it is rather sad to see the honourable member for Gellibrand ( Mr Willis) descending into a party political debate on what really ought to be a bipartisan approach to our national and foreign policy white paper. I do not know whether the member saw the Australian yesterday in which the opposition foreign affairs spokesman, the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith( Mr Brereton), is quoted as deriding the performance of the Keating government. The article said: In an extraordinary attack on his colleagues, Mr Brereton accused the former government of badly misjudging community feeling on French nuclear testing in the South Pacific during 1995 and putting obstacles in the way of a landmines ban rather than trying to find a solution. Mrs Bailey-That's refreshing honesty. known for that. However, he did point out that there was evidence of foreign policy fatigue during Labor's last months in government. It is obvious that was one of the reasons why the Labor Party was cast from office in March last year. Returning to this particular white paper on foreign and trade policy, it gives that policy a very sharp focus and it represents a coming of age of Australian foreign policy. I believe it is very important to recognise the white paper stresses that Australia's national interest will drive our approach in foreign and trade policy. In other words, we will make no apology whatsoever in international fora and elsewhere for standing up for what we believe is in the interest of this nation. I believe the courageous stand taken by the Prime Minister( Mr Howard) in relation to greenhouse emissions is another indication that this government is prepared to stand up and be counted for Australian jobs. The government's approach to greenhouse, particularly given the statement made by the Prime Minister last week, is fair and balanced and reasonable, and I believe that all of us ought to support it 100 per cent. Our approach to foreign and trade policy will aim to improve the security, the jobs and the standard of living of all Australians. It will do this in a number of ways. Firstly, there is a clear
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Slipper (Fisher) (12.10 P.m.)
theText: I am very pleased to participate in the debate whereby
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Slipper
theText: Unfortunately, the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith is not always11572 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 27 November 1997 recognition that Australia has global interests which require an active trade and foreign policy of broad scope. We believe that since we are in the Asia-Pacific region the Asia-Pacific region should be our first and highest priority, although not our only priority. The white paper is a public declaration, in effect, of our commitment to the Asia-Pacific region. It is vital to realise that our policy may be Asia first but it is not Asia only. Australia does have interests in other parts of the world and the white paper recognises that our interests are not limited to anyone region, although it stresses the very important role that our relationship with the Asia-Pacific region will play in the future. I must say that there is a great misconception in the Australian community over the benefits of trade liberalisation. Many people say to me that the reduction in tariffs means that we are costing Australian their jobs and that we are casting Australian families out of the work force. I believe that view is quite inappropriate. I am heartened by the bipartisan approach, largely, to trade liberalisation that exists between this government and its predecessor. It is always important to recognise that trade liberalisation has very many benefits for the Australian economy and for Australians. As a country which exports many products, we benefit more from trade liberalisation than some other countries do. Unfortunately, it must be noted that there are some short-term adjustment costs but even conservative estimates point out that the average Australian family has gained $1,000 per year from tariff reductions. A recent publication pointed out that families now have access to a wider range of affordable and high quality products, that imported cars would cost 25 per cent more if the 1988 tariffs still applied-which is an extra $5,000 to $20,000 a car-and that clothing and footwear would cost around 14 per cent more, which is an extra $300 or so, per year, for the average family to maintain its dress standards. It also pointed out that falls in trade barriers have contributed to a stronger industrial base, higher productivity, better access to international markets and new technologies and more competitive manufactured and services exports. While unfortunately some factories have closed, improved processing by other manufacturers, education, tourism and other services have produced good news. As other countries join us in trade liberalisation, there will be increased opportunities for Australian products and, as a result, we will create Australian jobs and our economy will be boosted. This is a policy that the former Labor government and this government have both supported. We ought not resile from the fact that we are in favour of trade liberalisation. The pauses in the areas of the motor vehicle and textile, clothing and footwear indistries that have occurred will create some increased investment but the overall policy is that tariffs should, must and will reduce because it is in the interests of Australia that this should happen. The former Labor government, to an extent, was sidetracked into indulging too much in multilateral international arrangements. We are certainly not opposed to multilateral arrangements but we believe there are very great advantages to Australia through bilateral arrangements whereby we are able to come to individual arrangements with individual countries to make decisions which are in Australia's national interests. In supporting the principle of bilateral relationships, we are not undermining the necessity for Australia to take its role in multilateral fora but the balance has changed with the change in government. The focus of our bilateral trade and investment efforts is very much on tailored and customised strategies. This means that different markets will need different levels of government support for Australian exporting and investors. I believe this is a very important Thursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 11573 change. Although the foreign policy of Australia does not automatically change with an alteration in government, and it has been largely bipartisan, this new emphasis on the importance of bilateral strategies is certainly an improvement which will work to Australia's interest. Over the next 15 years, our bilateral strategies will emphasise domestic regulatory elements and services. This will require Australia's trade negotiators to have a greater specialisation and expertise in areas such as barriers to services trade, intellectual property, investment impediments and anticompetitive behaviour by firms. This focus will be critical for Australia to capture its share of the high value-added activity in the international chain of production. We saw the Prime Minister playa key role in the recent APEC forum, and bilateral and regional fora will continue to provide means for pursuing bilateral objectives. The honourable member for Gellibrand mentioned certain comments made by the honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) in September 1996. I place on record my very grave concern at the impact that the comments made by the honourable member for Oxley are having in relation to our trade with South-East Asia. I have been to South-East Asia on a number of occasions and I have seen newspapers report those comments in a way that indicates that this nation is racist. I think most people in the chamber and most Australians would agree that we are one of the most tolerant countries in the world. The newspapers abroad, I believe, have done the wrong thing in so far as they have claimed that we are biased against people on the basis of race. That is clearly not the case. The simple fact of the matter is that newspapers in South-East Asia are read by people in the same way as newspapers here. The net result is that there could be some adverse impact on our exports to Asia. That would be tragic because Australia is very well located to export many things to South-East Asia, particular primary products, and the government's supermarket to Asia program is outstanding. We export an enormous percentage of Singapore's consumption of dairy products. One can go to many of the stores in Singapore and see Australian products everywhere on the shelves. emphasise that we are a tolerant nation. We should point out to them the reality of the situation. It is eminently regrettable, firstly, that the honourable member for Oxley's comments have been reported in this way and, secondly, that she has made some of those comments at all. Returning to this white paper, it is a very forward thinking document. It is a statement of commitment to the Asia-Pacific region. I believe that it will be supported by the Australian people and, ultimately, by the Labor Party as well. Happily, foreign policy is largely a matter of bipartisan approach by both parties in the parliament. It is absolutely essential that we recognise we are all about Asia first, but not Asia only. This country will benefit greatly as it seeks to work as part of the Asia-Pacific region, but there are also opportunities in other parts of the world. The white paper certainly recognises that those opportunities are there. I would like to congratulate the Minister for Foreign Affairs( Mr Downer) and the Minister for Trade( Mr Tim Fischer) on producing such a forward thinking document. The government ought to be commended for stating where we stand so clearly and so unequivocally. I believe that it is tragic that the honourable member for Gellibrand came into the committee today and sought to denigrate the wonderful job that this government has done in the area of foreign

speaker: Mr Nugent
theText: You've been to Tanglin market as well, haven't you?
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Slipper
theText: Indeed. I think that what we have to do as a nation is make sure that we11574 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 27 November 1997 affairs. The honourable member for Throsby laughs. The honourable member for Kingsford Smith yesterday said that the Labor Party suffered from foreign policy fatigue. Mrs Bailey-At least he had the courage to come out and say it. honourable member for Kingsford-Smith, but in doing so he condemned the honourable member for Holt( Mr Gareth Evans) and also Senator Ray. I would have liked very much to have been a fly on the wall when they reacted to the comments made by the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J. A. Crosio)-The member for Fisher has the floor; he does not need interjection to assist him in the debate. to know what the response of those two gentlemen was to that interesting attack by the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith. I suppose that they were not at all happy with him. This is a very important document; it is a positive document; it is an outstanding document. It states where the government stands, and I commend it to the chamber. Slipper). I think most people would agree that we would want a bipartisan approach on many foreign affairs issues, but that does not mean that we have to blindly follow everything that the government does. We are a different political party. We do take a different point of view on many issues. Where we can, we are happy to extend that bipartisanship in so many areas. Of course, we have the right as well to put an independent point of view on foreign policy where we see it as being appropriate. Let me at the outset make it clear that I welcome this white paper on Australian foreign and trade policy. I note that the Minister for Foreign Affairs( Mr Downer), said that the starting point of the paper is that an active foreign and trade policy is crucial to Australia's future security and prosperity. He went on to say that it is crucial because Australia has global interests and, as part of the global economy, its prosperity is tied to its performance as a trading nation. I agree entirely with this statement. Australia does have global interests and, for this reason, I am very concerned at the downgrading, cost-cutting and also closure of many of our diplomatic missions. I do not believe that in every country there should be an overseas mission or that every post of the overseas mission should be filled by totally Australian based staff. There is an argument for the employment of locally engaged staff, where appropriate; but I cannot understand why, if we have global interests, we are constantly cutting missions throughout the world. We are not represented in much of Africa, as indeed we are not in Latin America. Our posts in Africa are faced with an impossible task of adequately presenting Australia's case with constantly cut resources. For example, the post in Zimbabwe represents eight or nine African countries: it is just an impossible task. The same applies in Latin America. I am not for one moment suggesting that Australia should have a diplomatic mission in every country, but we are far too thin on the ground in far too many parts of the world.
