title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Hollis (Throsby) (12.24 P.m.)
theText: I listened to the honourable member for Fisher( MrThursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 11575 The closure of the post in Denmark was a mistake and will be seen to be a mistake. I still cannot understand why we do not have a mission in Addis Ababa, the headquarters of the Organisation of African Unity. One parliamentary delegation went to Ethiopia and recommended that we open a mission there. When the report came down, they accepted that recommendation and we opened a mission. It was in operation for 12 months and then it closed. The Canadians walked into the premises and got everything at a very low rate. The point that I am making about Addis Ababa is that it is the headquarters of the Organisation of African Unity and, if for no other reason than as a contact point or a listening point, I believe that the mission there should be reopened. There was much soul-searching and wringing of hands when Australia missed out last year on a position on the United Nations Security Council. MightI suggest that it was our lack of representation in Africa, especially francophone Africa, that contributed in part to our not achieving that position? The largest block of votes in the UN is the African nations. We have got a couple of missions in Africa and not one single post in francophone Africa. I am also concerned about the direction Australia is taking with regard to overseas aid, especially in relation to population programs. Australia's aid level today rates as 13th out of 21 in OECD countries. This is a drop from ninth in the previous year, and so Australia's aid ratio is falling. Australia has a responsibility to support the continuation of assistance for family planning programs, especially as part of an overall health strategy. Although the question of human rights is often difficult-and the honourable member for Aston( Mr Nugent) appreciates that it is a difficult situation-I do believe that we gain respect by speaking out on human rights issues. Having said that, it is important that our own human rights situation be beyond reproach. I am concerned that, on so many issues, Australia appears to be reneging on the strong commitment we had on these issues. The refusal regarding the human rights clause in the European Community treaty last year was ridiculous. We sent all the wrong messages about human rights and reinforced all the wrong prejudices that other countries have about us, in that we are prepared to pontificate, especially on human rights, yet we will not subject ourselves to the scrutiny we demand and expect of others. The cutting of funding to international bodies, such as the United Nations agencies, especially in relation to population programs, the cut in our funding to the International . Planned Parenthood Federation, and the cuts in the funding to the United Nations Fund on Population and Development are not worthy of Australia. In an overall budgetary context, it did not amount to a lot of money. To the organisations concerned, not 6nly was it a severe cut but, again, it sent all the wrong, negative messages. The honourable member for Fisher said that there should be a bipartisan approach to foreign policy issues. We on this side will not agree to sending all those wrong, negative messages, especially in relation to population issues and many, many other issues, and there is no way that we are going to support the government in what they are doing here. We are going to criticise them and raise the issues constantly so that hopefully in the next budget this funding will be restored. The same wrong message is being sent to the world regarding greenhouse gas emissions. I do not want to quote the honourable member for Fisher too much, but nevertheless during his speech, which I listened to with great interest, he did say that the Prime Minister( Mr Howard) did make a courageous statement on greenhouse gas emissions. The definition of 11576 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 27 November 1997 'courageous' is open to interpretation. I actually do not think it was a terribly courageous statement-when you are in a minority, when you are offside with most of the world. Now, again, greenhouse is a difficult issue and it is difficult for Australia. I represent a coal mining area; I know the issues involved in greenhouse. I am not saying for one moment that it is an easy issue-it is a difficult issue-but I do think that the message that we are sending from Australia on greenhouse gas emissions is a wrong message. The Prime Minister makes much of the fact that he is saving jobs, especially in coal areas such as my own. YetI have spoken to the miners in my area. Indeed a recent statement by John Maitland from the federation indicates that they do not support the Prime Minister's stand regarding greenhouse. Again, as I said before, we are sending a wrong and very negative message. For a government that wants to create a favourable image, we are certainly not going about it the correct way. As I am in areas critical of the government, let me make it clear that in one area I totally support the government and the action, and that is their decision on landmines. I have long opposed these dreadful destructive weapons, and indeed was critical of my side of parliament. I do not think we moved quickly enough on landmines when we were in government. When we were in power, my objection to landmines was equally strong, so I congratulate the government for moving quickly and decisively in this area. Managing foreign and trade policy is a challenge but governments are elected to meet these challenges. I do not think the government has shown the necessary leadership in this area and I believe that our image as a nation has been diminished by many of the stands that have been taken over recent months in the foreign policy area. I want to tum briefly to the comments made by the honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) in this debate about this time last week. I do not usually comment-I am not in the habit of commenting-on the utterances of the honourable member for Oxley as it only gives them some status. But her comments in this debate were so far over the top that they actually deserve some comment. Much as she may wish, Australia cannot divorce itself from the rest of the world. We live in an interdependent world. We have enough people arguing about internationalist conspiracy theories or pushing internatiopalist conspiracy theories without members of parliament peddling this trash. It always fascinates me when people talk about tourists coming to Australia on a foreign plane and on a national carrier and prepaying their accommodation. The member for Oxley quoted this. I personally do not know if the member for Oxley has ever been overseas, but, as good a patriotic Australian as she is, I suspect that, like me, if she went overseas, she would travel on our national carrier, Qantas. I guess she would pay for her fare in Australian dollars, in Australia, to Qantas-as Japanese tourists often pay and fly on their Japanese line and people from other countries fly on their national lines. When one goes overseas, one often pays for one's accommodation before one goes. I do. Sometimes, people even pay for side trips before they go. When I do that, I pay in Australia in Australian dollars. I do not see why people are so concerned if the Japanese--or the Italians, the Thais or whoever they are-fly on their national carrier and have prepaid their accommodation. We do it. Maybe they have paid in Thailand or Japan for a trip to the Blue Mountains, but if we want to go from Tokyo to somewhere else we pay in Australia, if we so want, to do that. This is a furphy that is pushed, about all these people flying on their national carrier. Why shouldn't they fly on their national carrier? I am always proud to fly Qantas. IfI have a choice Thursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 11577 of what airline I am going to fly on, I always fly Qantas. And, where appropriate, I prepay. You can often get a very good deal by prepaying your accommodation. SoI do not know why people keep talking about this. Other members have talked about the damage that has been done to Australia's image. I am old enough to remember the image Australia had. on the White Australia policy. It took us 30 years after that policy was changed-and, I will say before people interject, by the side of parliament opposite-to live that down. So many times when you went to Asia, or to Europe and places like that, people would still raise the White Australia policy with you. We suffered unnecessarily for that for many years. ' I honestly believe that we are going to suffer from the messages that the honourable member for Oxley is sending out. We are going to suffer for a long time, not only in the image of Australia we are trying to portray, but also from a financial point of view. The honourable member for Oxley made much of jobs-youth unemployment and loss of jobs in Australia. We all deplore the lack of employment and we all, on both sides, hope that we can make a contribution to restore that. But I would say something in all sincerity to the honourable member for Oxley. While we all can be critical-no-one is saying that the honourable member for Oxley cannot stand up in this parliament and be critical of parliament or of our government and so on; no-one argues with that and we are all, on both sides, critical of each other-the very policies that she is advocating and the messages she is sending out will ensure the loss of jobs in Australia. They will ensure a diminution of the living standard in Australia. That is why so many of us, on both sides of the parliament, are very critical of the comments of the honourable member for Oxley. What she says is a contradiction. She is just ensuring that what she purports to want for Australia will not be achieved. She is making a significant contribution to that. In that way, she is wrong and she should be criticised for what she is doing. I welcome the fact that the government has put out this policy on foreign affairs and trade. It gives us in this chamber an opportunity to debate it, albeit that two or three months have been spent in the waiting list. follow the honourable member for Throsby( Mr Hollis) in a debate on a different matter, and it is coincidence that I follow him today. As usual, his is a very thoughtful and considered contribution, and I thank him for that. I do not agree with everything he said and I will challenge him on a couple of those matters, but I certainly agree with a number of the issues that he has raised. PerhapsI should start by mentioning specifically his comments, and also those of the member for Fisher( Mr Slipper) who spoke before him, concerning the contribution that we have had from the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). There is no question that if one travels around in Asia, which is an important part of the world for our country these days, Australia's response to the views of the member for Oxley will be raised. I have had the opportunity this year to travel quite extensively, both on official delegations and in my capacity of holding office with various friendship groups. I have been to an IPO conference, I have been to Singapore and Malaysia, I have been to Hong Kong and China. Last year, I went to India and Pakistan. In talking to people in those countries, it is regrettable but still a fact that, although in formal exchanges you will not always have the subject of the
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Nugent (Aston) (12.39 P.m.)
theText: Yesterday, in the House, I had the opportunity to11578 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 27 November 1997 views of the member for Oxley raised---'it does happen on occasion-there is no doubt that in one-to-one conversations, 99 times out of 100, whether you are talking to MPs, Australian businessmen overseas or local business people, or people in the community, the possibility that Australia might agree in any substantive measure with the views expressed by the member for Oxley is, unfortunately, raised. People raise it in the context: 'Is it safe to invest in Australia; is it safe to send my child there to university; is it safe for my family and I to go to Australia for a holiday?' The reality of life is that if people have those concerns, and they do not have those concerns allayed, we will lose some of those people coming here for those various purposes. What that means is that the very things that the member for Oxley complains about-the loss of jobs and the loss of benefit to this country-will occur because we will not have the hotels so full, we will not have some investment in business ventures going ahead, and we will not have the education industry so well supported. And that earns us something like $2.8 billion a year; it is a very substantial industry. There are a number of factors that will determine whether or not people invest here, come here for a holiday or send their children here for university. The reality is that it is raised so frequently in so many countries that you cannot. help but feel that there has to be some negative impact. So it seems to me not only that from a moral point of view one might disagree with many of the One Nation comments, but that that party and the member for Oxley have to understand that by her utterances, which are repeated willy-nilly, unfortunately, by the media and are often not challenged as they should be, she is actually doing this countryand by implication, therefore, her constituents-positive damage. I think that needs to be pointed out on a regular basis. I would like to pick up a couple of the other comments from the gentleman from Throsby. He complained about the cost-cutting in Foreign Affairs of this government; he talked about the fact that we were closing missions. I have to say that we have not actually closed very many missions. The reality of life is that a lot of it comes down to money, and his government left us a huge debt. You cannot go on racking up debt forever. Sometimes you have to take some hard decisions and you often have to take decisions that you do not like taking. But I have to really take him to task in terms of his comments about our representation in Africa, saying that because we had closed posts in Africa we had lost the vote in the United Nations for a position on the Security Council. Frankly, that is absolute nonsense. The reality is that our lack of broad representation across the continent of Africa was something that occurred under the previous government, during their 13 years in office, and anything that we have done has frankly been peripheral and very recent in that regard. The reason that we did not get a lot of support from African countries in that United Nations vote was very much because we did not have representation-but we had not had it for years. People reflected in that vote the view that they had built up over a long period of time, not just something that had happened in the last few months. Remember, that vote occurred within the first year or so of our being in government. So, apart from the fact that one might have the view that Mr Butler could not count anyway and would never have made a good politician because he cannot count in things like voting, the reality was that that lack of support was a result of years of our lack of representation there. It is quite inappropriate to suggest that that is something brought on by this particular government. Thursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 11579 But we also have to understand-and it is part of what this white paper is all about-that you cannot run foreign affairs today the way you necessarily ran it 50 years ago, or 20 years ago, or even 10 years ago. Foreign affairs, like every other field of endeavour, has to change. What the white paper is about is trying to lay down some of the basic tenets. But the way we then operate within those basic tenets will, of course, change from time to time. In business and a whole range of other fields, and also in foreign affairs, we are going to be affected, for example, by technology. We have to recognise that. It is much easier to communicate with another country, to get information. It is much easier for the Prime Minister( Mr Howard) or the Minister for Foreign Affairs( Mr Downer) to fly off to a meeting to fix a problem. We do not necessarily need the huge structures that we had in individual countries in yesteryear for our representation because you could not get the senior politicians there in time to deal with some of those issues. It is an entirely different ball game. For example, one of the trends that is happening-and I think a very sensible, reasonable trend that is not going to adversely affect our relationships with other countries-is that we are starting to look at and experiment with the idea of sharing representation in countries. Perhaps Australia, in one country, might represent not only our interests but also those of Canada and maybe New Zealand. In another country, there might be a reciprocal arrangement, where Canada has a post and represents us, and that sort of thing. For example, I went to the IPO conference in Bali a few months ago. During a period when we were not actively engaged in the conference, contrary to the media perception that we might go and lie on the beach, we actually went off and looked at some of our aid projects. We visited our consul-general in Bali to have a look at what he was doing. In Bali, he represents Australia, New Zealand, Canada and Britain. He has got a regular job with the tourist trade to Bali from all those countries, unfortunately shipping home bodies, visiting people in gaol, replacing lost passports, dealing with people who have had their money lost or whatever it is-a whole range of problems that come from having large numbers of tourists in one place. He does a very good job on behalf of Australia and three other countries. Clearly, if we can develop reciprocal arrangements with some of those countries in other places to do the same sort of thing, we can have quite adequate representation without, in fact, having to say, 'Well, we have got to have a post in every country'. But we do not lose the quality of our representation. It seems to me that multilateral representation is quite interesting. It was interesting that the gentleman from Throsby specialised in talking about Africa. He has a special interest in Africa. Clearly, the white paper says that we have to focus on areas that are most important to us. It is not just about Asia, which is a critical area, but there are other parts of the world as well. There are parts of Africa which are of interest to us, but one has to be realistic and say that most of the continent of Africa is not at the top of our priority list. It does not mean that it is unimportant. Like the gentleman from Throsby, I am obviously concerned about our drop in aid, as I think many of us are. Unfortunately, one has to point out though that, whilst regretting the fact that aid is dropping, it is a trend that has been there for many years. I find it, frankly, somewhat disappointing that the gentleman from Throsby, who is normally, I think, sound on these issues, really wants to make a political point about the drop in aid when, under his government for so many years, that trend was in place as well, as it is with most OECD countries. Clearly, we are still in the top half, on a percentage basis, of aid givers in the OECD, but it is regrettable, in my view, that we are not able to get that up a bit. It seems to me that, once 11580 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 27 November 1997 we get the economy moving in the right direction-and we have done a number of things in the last 19 or 20 months as a government to do that-we will have much more wealth, much more disposable income, if you like, and that is when we, hopefully, will be able to start to get the aid going in the right direction. Under the previous government, aid dropped on a regular basis and, therefore, it is nonsense to start to point the finger in this direction. Clearly, a number of us in this parliament raise these human rights issues on a regular basis in a public way, as does the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister has raised a number of those issues with China, for example, and we have had open publicity about that. He has raised those issues with Indonesia. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has regularly raised those human rights issues, and he does so when he visits a whole range of countries. And there is a place to stand up and publicly raise those issues. But equally, it has been demonstrated over the years that just to stand up and make a noise is not always effective with every country. So one of the things this government has tried to do is to adopt a new approach to human rights by saying, 'If you like, we will do less head kicking with other countries in public on human rights. We will try to develop our relationships and to raise some of these things in private in the hope that, on a friendly basis, we will start to have a bit more influence in actually achieving something.' We are only 18 or 19 months down the track of that new approach, but it seems to me that previously, although we made a lot of noise and there was a lot of rhetoric, we were not always successful in achieving the results we desired. Therefore, it is worth trying a new approach. I think it is too early; I think the jury is still out in terms of whether the new approach has been successful, but after two, three, four or five years we will obviously start to see the results. It seems to me that it is rather fruitless just to condemn a new approach without giving it time to work. I really have to protest at the European Union comment made by the member for Throsby. He argued that we were not prepared to sign off a trade agreement because it had human rights elements linked to it. The reality of life is that not only has that matter been satisfactorily resolved to the satisfaction of Europe as well as to our satisfaction, but that in fact his government took exactly the same position when it was negotiating on exactly the same issue. So the previous government was taking no different an official position from that of the Howard government. I am obviously pleased that the member for Throsby acknowledged the support for the position on landmines. This government was also extremely successful with things like the nuclear test ban treaty, which was a major achievement of this government. The white paper is an important document, and it is important to recognise that it is the first time that the government-any Australian government-has laid down its foreign policy thrust. It is important that people understand where we are coming from, what our priorities are and what it is we want to do. That does not mean that things will not change or that there may not be change to react to different circumstances as they develop. It is not to say that over a period of time there may not be some variation. But it is very helpful to have a basic understanding of where Australia is going in terms of foreign affairs, and it is very important to understand where we are going on trade policy. Of course we will have differences as time goes by; of course we will have arguments about whether you link trade to human rights and whether you do it openly or quietly. Thursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 11581 It seems to me that the proof of the pudding is in the eating and, whilst the previous government certainly had its foreign policy successes, this government has had its foreign policy successes. Historically, we have generally followed a bipartisan foreign policy approach and I very much hope that that will continue. It seems to me that there are lot of good things in this paper which the opposition should be able to agree with, and I certainly commend the document to the House. Dr SOUTHCOTT (Boothby) (12.53 p.m.)-In the 50 years in which Australia has had a distinctive, independent foreign policy-as the member for Aston( Mr Nugent) said-this is the first white paper which actually sets out our foreign and trade policy framework. In the evolution of Australia's foreign policy, the white paper is significant for detailing that globalisation and the rise of East Asia are likely to be the two most important influences which will affect Australia as it enters the next century. It also notes that, as the centre of gravity of the world's economy shifts from the Atlantic to the Pacific, Australia's future will lie in a successful integration in Asia. As the Prime Minister( Mr Howard) has stated, this does not mean that we have to choose between our history and our geography, but rather that we must recognise that Australia faces a significant national challenge in engaging with our regional neighbours. Paul Keating promoted the idea that he was a modem day Vasco da Gama, a modem day Marco Polo, a man who discovered the east-which his predecessors had somehow overlooked. During the last election, he promoted the idea that regional leaders would not deal with John Howard as Prime Minister. Subsequently, successful meetings with Prime Minister Mahathir, President Suharto-on two occasions-President Jiang Zemin of China and Prime Minister Hashimoto have shown that Asian leaders are comfortable dealing with Prime Minister Howard and that Keating's accusations actually ignore the fact that recognising the importance of the Asia-Pacific over the next two decades is not the exclusive preserve of the ALP. The importance of East Asia is not a new notion. As far back as the 1950s, Richard Casey recognised that Australia's relations with the emerging post-colonial nations in our region would be important to our future. Initiatives such as the Colombo Plan not only assisted developing countries in Asia but changed Australia through the person to person contact they created between young Australian students and their Asian counterparts. The negotiation of the Australia-Japan trade treaty in 1957, the abolition of the White Australia policy under Harold Holt and the recognition of China under Whitlam were all important landmarks in Australia's relations with Asia over the last 50 years. The future for Australia in the 21st century is as aconfident and open nation that accepts the challenges of competing in the international economy and the challenges of engagement in the region. On a strategic, cultural and economic level, engagement with Asia will be critical and will require foresight and flair to be successful. As the economies of ASEAN and NorthEast Asia continue to grow, and as the programs of military modernisation update the armed forces of East Asia, Australia will need to work hard to maintain its relative influence. The alternative, a failure to integrate in Asia, a failure to maintain our level of influence as a medium-level power, and retreating to a being a protected and insecure country, just does not bear contemplation. Our goal should be to be a nation in the South Pacific with European traditions, but a country that is comfortable dealing with the different cultures and languages of the Western Pacific rim, and that is able to work in a coalition of shared interests. Our expertise in Asian studies should be expanded, and many young Australians should consider 11582 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 27 November 1997 improving their Asian language skills to improve our business and official links with Asia, and also our understanding of Asia. The white paper clearly rebuts many of the myths which are being propagated by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) with her dangerous brand of xenophobic protectionism. The white paper shows that over the last 10 years, Australia has become a more open economy. Trade in goods and services has increased from 35 per cent of GOP to 40 per cent of GOP, and over 60 per cent of our exports are now sent to East Asia. The white paper also demonstrates unequivocally that this increase in exports has created jobs, and that those jobs pay more. Surveys in 1995 and 1996 showed that firms which export are increasing employment faster than non-exporters, they are more productive, and they pay better salaries. The paper also shows that since the 1950s, rural commodities have declined as a proportion of our exports as services, manufactures, and non-rural commodities became more important. That has become particularly noticeable over the last 15 years. As tariff protection has fallen, Australia's elaborately transformed manufactures have increased as firms' competitiveness has increased. For example, cuts in tariffs from 30 per cent in 1987 to around 5 per cent in 1996 have seen medical and scientific equipment increase their exports from $300 million in 1987 to $700 million in 1996. It is not just Australia that is reducing its tariffs alone in a protected world. Since 1988, most East Asian nations have reduced their tariffs significantly. ASEAN nations have cut their tariffs on a trade weighted basis by about two-thirds between 1988 and 1995. Professor Peter Drysdale of the ANU has pointed out that 77 per cent of the increase in exports that we have seen over the last 10 years went to East Asia. To quote Professor Drysdale, he said: Australia sends more of its growth in its exports to the countries of East Asia than does any .other country in the world, including any in East Asia itself. The recent currency and financial market turmoil which has now affected every country in East Asia has raised questions about the ability of East Asia to continue the stunning growth rates of the 1980s and 1990s. On balance, the opinion seems to be that if these nations are able to correct the weaknesses in their financial systems, maintain political stability, in the medium term manage several leadership transitions, and improve their current account deficits and the high levels of debt, then East Asia is likely to continue its high levels of growth. Dealing with globalisation and maintaining support for policy reforms will be a significant political challenge for all governments in the next century. World trade and investment are growing much faster than the world economy. The white paper correctly identifies 'that trade liberalisation and an open economy contribute to economic growth and job creation', which refutes the common notion that tariff protection actually protects jobs and reducing levels of tariffs actually leads to job losses. Much of the growth in international trade has come in the services sector and that will continue. Services comprise about 21 per cent of world trade now and that is projected to rise to 27 per cent by the year 2010. As a consequence, critical comparative advantages for nations in the 21st century will be an openness to new technology, high levels of education and a culture of innovation. In an article in the summer 1997 edition of Foreign Policy, Professor Dani Rodrik of Harvard University has tried to make sense of many of the myths that exist about globalisation. Thursday, 27 November 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 11583 His thesis is that globalisation can improve a nation's overall national income but that in advanced countries this can sometimes be at the expense of a decline in wages of unskilled workers. Professor Rodrik said that 'globalisation does not constrain national autonomy nearly as much as popular discussions assume.' In the paper he also highlights the significant political challenge that results from the process of globalisation. Politicians such as Buchanan in the United States, Zhirinovsky in Russia, Le Pen in France and, in Australia, the member for Hotham( Mr Crean) hand in hand with the member for Oxley, show that opposing globalisation, through a brand of neoprotectionism, can gain some political support. It is actually a much more politically challenging task to go out and sell something notional, which is free trade, against something more concrete and tangible but also harmful, which is protectionism. The article does not minimise the significant dislocation that can occur as a result of globalisation. While the benefits of this process are distributed more evenly, those who pay a cost for freer trade are often clearly found. The policy challenge is to sell, as this paper does, the benefits for Australia in globalisation and also to make sure that education, training and the social security net can minimise the impact for those who do not prosper in a globalised economy. As Rodrik says: National policymakers must not retreat behind protectionist walls. Protectionism would be of limited help, and it would create its own social tensions. Policy makers ought instead to complement the external strategy of liberalisation with an internal strategy of compensation, training and social insurance for those groups who are most at risk. Globalisation will continue to be influential with political, social and economic dimensions. Globalisation means that nations will have to account ultimately for poor fiscal and monetary policy. One of the lessons from 1997 must be that, when the firestorm was engulfing the equity markets and the currencies of most Asian economies, Australia was only minimally affected. As Paul Kelly highlighted in the Australian of 26 November, 'Asia's crisis reveals Australia's assets in terms of its economic fundamentals, its sophisticated financial system and its liberalisation of trade credentials.' The Howard government's lead by turning a $10 billion deficit into a budget surplus over three years helped Australia withstand that Asian turmoil. The budget turnaround was opposed by Labor but without this improvement in our fiscal position not only would interest rates be higher but it is likely that our equity markets and exchange rate would have come under more pressure. Our low inflation, low mortgage interest rates and successful privatisation of Telstra are underpinned by policies that were opposed by the Australian Labor Party. The implementation of the Wallis inquiry recommendations will build on the reputation of our financial system in the key areas of consumer protection and prudential regulation. Australia has moved from Paul Keating's banana republic of 10 years ago to be a beacon in our region for fiscal prudence and financial sophistication. In the section of the paper dealing with regional trade agreements I would like to sound a word of caution. There is nothing wrong with regional trade agreements per se. The closer economic relationship with New Zealand and APEC are both examples of regional agreements that Australia belongs to which do not undermine the World Trade Organisation or global free trade. They do not divert trade. However, customs unions or free trade areas which do not offer liberalisation on a most favoured nation basis, and are not open to entry for other nations, are likely to divert trade and actually undermine the principles of multilateral trade liberalisation. 11584 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 27 November 1997 I believe that, while bilateral trade agreements may offer a tangible short-term gain, the underlying principle for Australia's trade policy must be a commitment to multilateral trade liberalisation under the World Trade Organisation and also a commitment to the concept of open regionalism, which was defined by Ross Garnaut and Peter Drysdale at the ANU as embodied in organisations such as APEC, which do offer liberalisation on a most favoured nation basis to non-participants of the regional organisation. The advantage of regional trade agreements may be a more wieldy, more rapid liberalisation, but it is important that they are WTO consistent and do not lead to any sort of trade diversion. I think the white paper states very clearly and importantly what Australia's priorities will be as we approach the next century. It does offer a framework in a very transparent way to say what Australia will be prioritising in terms of our foreign policy. It is only a framework. It is a framework which we will work within. I commend the paper to the House. Debate (on motion by Mr Anthony) adjourned. Main Committee adjourned at 1.07 p.m ..
